title: Have you witnessed anything noticeable happen immediately after someone dies? - Quora

response.answer_text: Absolutely. And it was shocking, if not dramatic. Several years ago, I got a call on a brilliant Sunday morning from my ex. She was distraught because she had learned her father -- who I'd known for several years -- had had a medical emergency and was in a coma at the neurological center at one of the best medical facilities in Washington, Harborview in Seattle. The event had occurred on Friday immediately prior and his "new" family had waited two days to let her know. She and he had been estranged for over a year, you see. Estranged over very petty things, it turned out. But, on with the story. My ex asked me to accompany her to the hospital, which I naturally agreed to do. I have lost loved ones in my life, but I had never seen a person on full life support. It is an awesome and disturbing sight. In the center of a large room the person lies on a very elaborate bed, with machines on either side, tubes coming and going to and from the body. And there is the quiet "whoosh, whoosh" sound of the breathing apparatus. The adult children of Jim's second wife (my ex's mom had died five years earlier after a short battle with cancer) were there. My ex's only sibling, her sister, was also there. This was not a matter of a vigil. There was no hoped-for recovery, however faint. The doctors took my ex, her sister and me aside and explained that Jim was, for all intents and purposes, quite dead, but his body could be kept alive indefinitely. The question was put to the sisters: what do you choose to do? Keep life-support or let him go? The sense I had was that the doctors really knew what the best thing to do was. The sisters did too. It did not take them long to make the decision to stop the extraordinary measures. The next part of the process was explained to everyone by the nursing team, matter-of-factually, but with kindness and compassion. They explained it would take several moments to prepare Jim for the final phase and they invited us to leave for coffee while they prepared him and they would contact us to return at "the moment." That "moment" is the one you hear so much tell of: the moment when they "pull the plug." But, before we left for the hospital cafeteria, the nursing staff allowed the sisters a moment alone with Jim. Now, to be clear, there was nothing shocking or off-putting throughout this part of the process. Jim looked -- despite the tubes -- for all the world to be in a peaceful sleep. He looked .... "normal." After the sisters made their farewells, we left for the cafeteria. There, we spoke of Jim, told stories, spoke of how we felt. There was even some laughter at a remembered anecdote. And there were tears. More than anything, there was nervousness. None of us -- not his step children, not my ex or her sister, and certainly not me -- had ever actually watched a person die before, let alone someone we cared for. We had probably all seen people in death, but nothing like this. In other words, we didn't know what to expect. Speaking only for myself, I was not prepared for what would happen next. Finally, after about forty minutes we were summoned from the cafeteria and we reassembled to the room in the intensive care section. All the tubes had been removed, save for the breathing tube. But for that, Jim looked even more as though he'd just laid down for a Sunday afternoon nap. His face and arms were slightly tanned by the summer sun we'd been experiencing. There was the quiet "whoosh, whoosh" of the breathing machine. One of the doctors, the neurologist, explained what would happen next. He told us that they would remove the breathing tube but that death would not be instantaneous. He also told us something that was actually quite chilling: there was no telling how long it might take or even IF his body would give up. We were told it was possible, but not very likely, that Jim would actually start breathing on his own. But the doctor assured us, more than once, that whatever happened, Jim would experience no pain whatsoever. The breathing machine was turned off and the gentle "whoosh, whoosh" sound stopped and the room became nearly silent. The nurse removed the breathing tube. There was a heart monitor that had a visible display but, the "beep, beep" sound was not on. Then we waited. It did not take long. Within less than five minutes, the visible heart monitor bleeps slowed and elongated to a steady line. Then the most shocking thing -- at least for me -- happened. Jim turned ashen grey -- as grey as coals on a winnowing fire. The kiss of the summer sun left him utterly. We didn't need to watch the heart monitor. We all knew instinctively that the remaining life force that was in him was in him no more. We could not know where it went, but we were certain it wasn't there, in Jim, anymore. The silence in the room was deafening. I believe everyone was in shock. There was no weeping. There were no gasps. Just... Silence.

As a nursing home nurse of many years…….we could probably every one of us answer this question. Some nurses write books based on their death and dying events……and I have had several events but I will give you two such events. About 18 years ago, maybe 20….I was working in a very large facility in the SW…..and I had a resident whom I’ll call Ms. Smith. She was a very kind, very elderly woman, one son who managed the family business. She had blindness and heart issues. One night she became very ill and was shipped out to the hospital. When she was ready to discharge back to us, our medical director who was following Ms. Smith at the hospital as well, he called me to discuss her new orders. In the nursing profession we are given very strict rules on how to administer medications…especially meds like morphine. So basically she had a mitral value that was not allowing all of her blood to travel forward on it’s natural path, she was having what they call “backwash”…..which meant her blood in her legs at this point, was not moving back up to her heart as is normal for the body to do. He said it was a very painful condition and he wanted me to inject her with morphine IM every hour, but he could only write the order for once every 2 hours. Did not matter if she requested it or not, give her the shot every hour on the hour because they were sending her back to us to die among people she knew. So I talked to all my staff and basically we just all made sure that one of us was with her at all times. Even the nursing assistants donated their time off to sitting with her. During this time she never once said she was in pain, she did not even reflect pain in her face, which puzzled all of us, the doctor included. For two weeks we all kept up this vigil, I guess you’d call it that…I was a dayshift charge nurse but we didn’t have a regular 3–11p nurse so I worked the extra shift so I could do my part. During this time me and the staff, well she was having conversations with family and friends who had gone on before her, according to her son. About a week and a half into this, she started having conversations with her dead husband, he’d been dead since the son was a young boy. And she was arguing with him. Apparently he was telling her come on it’s time but she felt her place was here with her son and grandson. We all listened to her fussing with him for 2 maybe 3 days. It occurred to me that perhaps if the son would tell her that they were fine, go be with Dad, that she’d be okay with that and go be with her husband. So he did do that but still she clung on. Now I knew her to be a devoted christian, according to her son, her entire life, having been saved as a little girl. The last night I was sitting with her in her room, I had my med books with me, going thru them making sure I hadn’t missed anything and she asked me if I could see the angel hovering above her head or the one at the end of her bed. I noticed that her face was really luminous. I told her yes, that they had come to take her to dance with Jesus. She smiled at that, closed her eyes….her breathing slowed and when she took her last breath….she was smiling ear to ear, at peace…face glowing like nothing I’ve ever seen before then or even after. I have been asked many times over the years if I believed in an after life and I tell them this event. I always reply, “I do now”………The other event I will tell you about is short. I was working the night shift, fresh from my two days off…..and I went to do my assessment on the new patient that had been brought to us in a coma. The lady had been in a coma at the hospital for two months apparently. She was being fed via a stomach tube. So I went in with a nursing assistant who was very talkative that night. Her father was a Pentecostal preacher. So she’s talking away while getting this woman’s vital signs and I’m changing out the feeding tube bottle when suddenly this woman sat straight up in the bed, kicking her feet like she was paddling in the water trying to back up or something….screaming “It’s burning! It’s burning!”, a look of fear on her face I will never forget, if I live to be 100 I will never forget that look of fear. Then she fell back in the bed and was dead. Seriously. My nursing assistant screamed and threw the blood pressure cuff into the air and ran out of the room. Me, I’m trying to get a pulse, etc. So I’m trying to get the assistant to come back and help me but she refused. So I told her to go get one of the other nursing assistants. Well I had three nursing assistants that night on my unit. Dee, the preacher’s daughter, Tate, the older lady from Jamaica who also refused to go into the room….she said that her people believed that if you touch the body after such an event that the toucher would be cursed. Okay so by now I am very angry and frustrated so I yelled, get your ass up the hall and get Dawkins then! In this nursing home in early 1990’s, we addressed each other by last names…..Dawkins was from Chicago and she didn’t take no shit from anyone…..she ripped the bp cuff out of Tate’s hands and told them both to get the f**k out of her way and we proceeded to do our jobs….then I called her daughter on the chart. It was very strange and no, I did not tell the two daughters the circumstances….just that she had died peacefully. I do not believe in telling the family negative stuff that sometimes happens when people die. I just can’t see that it serves any good purpose. I had not as yet met either of these two women but they seemed relieved. Detached perhaps is a better word. They both hugged me and thanked me, saying they were sure I must have done everything that could be done, without really asking me what exactly I did do……..it was like the words were there but no feeling at all. What is weird about this event to me is….I’ve been saved since I was 18 years old. But being a nursing home nurse? You see all kinds of pain and suffering and it’s hard to deal with sometimes. Lots of nurses end up burned out. All my life all I wanted to be was a good nurse who gave comfort to folks. Naive, probably. Some things you just have no control over whatsoever. So I was at a time in my life where I was seriously doubting the existence of a God who could let people suffer like they do. Well, this last event happened a couple of years before the first one but after the one where the woman was scared to death? Yeah…that’s all it took for me to get my mind back on track, studying my bible and figuring out why exactly it is that people suffer in this life. And that topic can and does get debated by people probably everyday of the year……but as for me? Nah, I have no doubt whatsoever. I hope this helps you in some way.

I have experienced the death of 53 people in my life. 2 of these death were people were my closest compadres! The first was my soulmate. lover, the most incredible person I have ever met. We spent 20 + years together in monogamous relationship. When I came out as a Gay male during my senior year in High School I was abandoned by my family. If you read my other posts you can understand what I went through. I met my Soul Mate Johnny during my Freshman year in college. I was totally smitten by his looks, his incredible physical stature, and most of all his caring and loving nature. It did not take long for us to begin the journey on he Road of Life. Both of us were effectively orphans as he too had no family. Both of us were Native New Yorkers. We shared many interests but most of all our souls were intertwined in a Graceful Tapestry of Love. We were dedicated to faithfulness and as such were totally monogamous. Were both involved in the Stonewall Rebellion which gave rise to the GLBTQ liberation movement. But after Stonewall, the mindset of the Gay male community became more promiscuous. Johnny and I moved to Florida in 1980. We bought an House in the ART Deco region of Miami. Our lives were wonderful. He became a head chef at one of the largest Hotels on Miami Beach. I opened my own Dance Studio and theme Party business. An unfortunate Kitchen accident would soon change our lives forever. Johnny had a mishap in the kitchen of the Hotel. He was sent to the hospital and was told he needed a blood transfusion. I rushed to the hospital that day an offered to donate blood. Unfortunately, our blood types were incompatible. Thus he received blood from the hospital. Blood supplies were not screened in those days. A few months later the first symptoms would begin. Skin rashes and respiratory symptoms prevailed at first. Johnny went back o the hospital but the doctor’s did not know what they were dealing with. Soon many other’s in the Gay community were coming down with similar symptoms. At first the disease had no name but it was definitely more prevalent in he Gay male and African American population. Soon it was called the “Gay Cancer”. The population at large didn’t care about the strange infection because it affected what they referred to as a “marginal population. Soon it was discovered that the disease was being spread by a virus that affected the human immune system. The virus was called HIV. The disease was soon named AIDS. Johnny was one of the first reported cases. It was deemed that he contacted the disease via the recent blood transfusion. But the disease was being spread through unprotected sex and drug use. Both Johnny and I were totally monogamous and neither of us used substances of any kind! From the onset of the infection Johnny was given a cadre of medications, most of which were as bad as the disease. Johnny was a 195 pound bodybuilder who worked out 5 days a week. Over 4 years and 5 trips to the hospital, he shrank to a 90 pound corpse. On the 6th trip, I decided I would not let him die in the Hospital. We were not married but he was all I had and our souls were inseparable. On Valentines day 1984 he died in my arms. I could feel his life slip away as I held him in a final embrace. I made him a promise to remain faithful. FAITHFUL IN LIFE FAITHFUL IN DEATH! I have been celibate since 1983 (before his death) and remain as such. I am now asexual and will remain as such!! I LOVE YOU JOHNNY and I miss you. But I will see you again when I cross the Rainbow Bridge and run into your arms. I still see him in my dreams. I have his ashes and I will mix my ashes with his when my time comes. Our ashes will be spread in several places. The better part of us will dropped off the EMPIRE STATE BUILDING-WE WILL BE A HIT ON BROADWAY! The second death that affected me was the death of my childhood best friend. His name was Chuck and I first met him in Summer camp. I had gone to the same Summer camp from the year 1950 until 1968. Chuck and I met when we were kids age 6. It would turn out that we would share parallel lives. Both of us had a strong interest in insects and would become serious amateur entomologists. If that were not enough, both of us were gifted academically. To add to the mix, both of us began dancing, me at 5 and Chuck at 6. We would both go on to become professional dancers later in life. By age 8 Chuck and I were both child comparative dancers, specializing in Ballroom, Latin, Swing Dance and Hustle. I lived in New York and Chuck lived in Philadelphia. We would get together after summer camp season at various entomological society meetings, especially the Lepidopterist Society. By 1965 I had come out as a GAY male. As coincidental as it may sound Chuck came out a year later. I was already involved with my Soulmate Johnny. In fact Chuck became a good friend of Johnny’s after being introduced. Our Entomological pursuits often involved the 3 of us. When Johnny and I moved to Florida, Chuck often visited. Chuck became our best friend. Both Chuck and I had become professional dancers and had successful dance businesses. When Johnny passed away in 1984, Chuck was there to offer support. I moved back to New York from Miami Florida in 1985, I sold the house that Johnny and I had bought and most of my Art Deco collectibles to pay for the exorbitant medical bills that Johnny had occurred. Back home in New York, I became involved in various AIDS support groups. I watched as people were dropping like flies. I lost 50 + people to the growing Pandemic. Chuck and I would go on collecting trips to most of the USA. We also collected in many foreign lands such as:Costa Rica,Brazil,Ecuador, Peru, French Guiana, Belize and many other entomological wonderlands. My collection grew as did Chuck’s. Soon we both had “Bug rooms” in our homes. Chuck and I often traveled to Arizona where I now live. During the summer of 1991, The Lepidopterists Society was to meet in August. Chuck was going to the meeting and I was planning on flying out to meet him on Aug 7,1991. I called him on the 5th of August and asked him to book 3 weeks at the Santa Rita Lodge in Madera Canyon, a well known collecting locality. Early on the morning of Aug 6,1991 I received a phone call from Chuck’s mother. She was crying as she spoke to me “Ira-they found Chuck Dead in a motel room”. I was in shock, I had just spoken to him yesterday, I said to his Mother. I was to fly to meet him tomorrow morning. And meet him I did, at the local Morgue in Tucson. I Identified the body and called his mother back home in Philadelphia where she was living. On Aug 10 I attended his funeral, an open casket service. I was a complete wreck. In attendance were several members of Chucks Dance Class and several members of a Gay natural History Group that Chuck was actively participating . The members of the group informed me that Chuck had contacted AIDS during 1990. Chuck had not informed me of his condition! He probably spared me the details due to all the grief I had already experienced. Chuck was gone and I headed back to New York City. 2 nights after the funeral I was having trouble sleeping. After several hours of tossing and turning I was able to fall asleep. About 3 AM I awakened to what I thought was a dream. BUT NO I WAS WIDE AWAKE. THE ROOM FILLED WITH BRIGHT LIGHT. OUT OF THE LIGHT FLEW A BUTTERFLY. I BEGAN TO SOB AND CRY OUT LOUD! NEXT CAME A SERENE VOICE OUT OF THE LIGHT WHICH SAID “DON”T WORRY ABOUT CHUCK, HE’S WITH US. Later on that week I was told by several friends that I did not hallucinate, I experienced a vision! 6 months to the date of Chuck’s death I moved to Tucson. I needed a change. CHUCK, DEAR FRIEND, I WILL SEE YOU AND JOHNNY WHEN I FINALLY CROSS THE RAINBOW BRIDGE! I MISS BOTH OF YOU! I now travel life’s road alone. I do have friends in Tucson and one good friend left in New York, another Entomologist. But I do look forward to seeing my soulmate and best friend again in Heaven!

Yes, and only a few people actually believe this. I flew home to be with my father when he was passing, and I chose the date and time because my husband told me my father had given him orders to send me home during his meditation, ( my husband’s). When I arrived my step-mother greeted me at the airport and took me straight to the facility in which my father lived. He had spent the last year and a half I in an assisted living facility, and he had had Alzheimer’s for eight years Roughly. This was 11:00 at night. When we arrived at the facility, the full moon looked so close, like in the film Bruce Almighty, when Jim Carrey is given supernatural abilities and pulls the moon closer to Earth in order to enjoy it more. And there’s one more distinguishing trait here. The moon was Red. A deep blood red. My step-mother also remarked upon how full and red the moon was, so I was grateful to have confirmation. Bracing myself for stranger things, I went into my father’s room. Earlier in the day, during the flight, my step-mother had kept me apprised of his breathing, which was becoming more staggered, and I was worried he might have died in the interim of time she had taken to retrieve me from the airport. Luckily, when I walked in, he was still breathing. I sat with him and held his hand, and observed his gaunt body, the bed-sores, his gnarled long toenails. In a thin hospital gown, this was the end of my father, a complicated, but lovely man. Maybe after sitting with him for ten minutes, I began to speak. I told him to find his spiritual guide, and to get on the boat that would take him away. I told him to trust the ferryman, and that now was the perfect time to sail. In his youth, my father owned a sailboat, so I hoped he’d enjoy that image. His breath rose less immediately and then, just like that, he passed. My step-mother and I sat there for a few moments, taking it in, and then she suggested she call for the hospice nurse. I watched my father for several moments, keenly. I touched the crown of his head and recited a Buddhist mantra several times. I prayed he would be delivered into a safe place, because I knew he was afraid of what happens after death. He never vocalized any belief, although, I know he appreciated mine and had been my definitive guide to it all my life. And then it happened. Smoke began to billow out of his mouth and curled up into the ceiling. I watched, stunned, and that’s when my step-mother asked me what I saw. I said, “"you don't see the vapor, do you?” I just knew this time the vision was mine. No, she shook her head and peered into my father’s mouth, while smoke, or vapor, seeped out of him in a long trailing fashion. It went on that way for several minutes, and as much as I wanted to touch it, I dared not, because I felt like that would be wrong. When the hospice nurse arrived, we told her what I saw, and she just nodded, as if she’s heard everything and wasn't surprised. We stayed a few minutes more, and then left around mid-night, just one hour from our arrival.For the next few days, various people reported being bothered in the night by something they could only describe as my father. My mother saw a glowing red light by her bed, and my twin sister, who is not intuitive in the least, said she told our father to leave her alone the night before his memorial. I was saddened to not be believed by my loved ones, but I do think that I was extremely lucky to say goodbye to my father and to pay close enough attention to the signs of his passing. I hope he found his way to a better place.

I don’t know if every case is the same so I can only share what happened in my grandfather’s case. My grandfather contracted pneumonia and started deteriorating quite quickly and nobody knew why or what was happening (please always go to more than one doctor for advice). Only after he died did we actually find out his lung capacity was minimal due to having worked with chemicals over the years and they now severely prevented his lungs from expanding like they should. So as a result of the lack of oxygen, the effects of death were noticeable quite quickly. I was by his bedside at 4 am in ICU and he was sleeping with a gas mask on. He was very scared the night before so i didn’t want to wake him and make it worse, he was peaceful. So I held his hand and he was still warm, I told him I loved him and prayed for him that he could still fight if he wanted to. As time went by, he was getting significantly colder and due to the lack of oxygen and blood pressure, the heart couldn’t keep up and it went from something crazy like 144 beats to 60 rapidly and I started crying, asking him to say and I hugged him and gave him one last kiss on the cheek. The nurse explained to us when we arrived his vital organs weren’t getting the oxygen they needed and they can’t raise the blood pressure because the heart beats were already so high. So I grabbed his hand again at 5:15, so much colder than before and watched the machine go from 60 to 68 and then to 0. The nurse asked us to step outside while they took all the tubes off and then she’ll call me back when she was finished. 10 minutes later his fingers were already going blue, but not at the tips - on the undersides and was spreading like dots. He was cold. His mouth was open when he died and I saw the nurse try close it before I left but it fell open again. When I came back, it stayed closed by itself. I stayed for a bit, crying by his bedside and prayed for his peace and when the funeral home arrived shortly after, I grabbed his shoulder and told him “sleep well”. When I grabbed his shoulder though, he was already rigged and his whole body shifted. An experience that has scarred me and will probably never forget. I wasn’t expecting that. 3 days later, April 8th was the funeral and it was an open coffin. He looked a little bloated, his lips PALE and skin starting to sag back. I also noticed he had tiny bit of blood around his mouth and corner of his eyes. I will never go through that again, no deathbeds, no open coffins. It was enough for a lifetime. I’m no doctor and because this happened only recently medical facts may be wrong but experiences wont be. RIP gramps. I miss you everyday.

I was present when my mother and my father breathed their last breath. I was alone with them both times. From my observations, there are two things that I noticed once they passed. I will describe both incidents separately. MOM My mother passed away on June 3rd, 2016 at approximately 5:15 and 5:30 in the morning. She had lung cancer and I slept in the room with her and made sure she was never alone. Hence, my dad and I had ‘shifts’. I had the night shift. At first, I was deathly afraid of the idea the she would pass away in my presence. Yet, I did not want my dad to be alone if she would pass away either. Knowing my mom, she would somehow find a way to make things OK. In a weird way, it was comforting to hear her heavy breathing. I mean, near the end, she had a lot of morphine and she did not respond to us and her breathing was very difficult and labored. ( I believe in English the proper word is heaving.) Anyway, at around 4:45 am, the nurse came in the room with the flashlight pointing to the ceiling. I woke up and listened. My mom was still breathing and after the nurse left, I looked at the clock and I realised I had about an other hour of sleep before I would get up. I puffed my pillow on my cot and looked up at my mom. ( My cot was lower than her bed) I closed my eyes and had the deepest sleep from 4:50 to 5:10. ( To this day, I have not slept as deeply as that time and I cannot recall if I ever slept that deeply.) I woke up and sat on my cot in a very sudden movement that was to a degree subconscious: something was wrong. There was silence. TOTAL SILENCE. It was the loudest silence that I ever heard. It was as if time had stood still. My mom had passed away. She was no longer suffering. I got up, went to her side and she was still warm and I fixed her hair as best as I could and kissed her forehead and told her that I loved her and then, I swear, I felt something behind me and I turned and looked outside. I then noticed that my mother was facing the window and as she passed she was looking at the sunrise. I saw the most beautiful rays of sunshine that seemed to beam from her body to the sky. The rays of sunshine seem to have all kinds of colours from the rainbow. It was so comforting and gentle. My mom is the first and only human being that I witnessed pass away in my presence and I believe that somehow she did what she could to comfort me even after she was gone. I turned my head towards her and even though tears were pouring down my face, I was happy and sad at the same time. I was happy because she was no longer suffering and sad because my mom was gone on the other side of eternity and I could not go visit her. EVER. Also, her body was not longer the cage of her soul. She was set free. I then somehow managed to walk towards the nurse’s station and said in French: “ ‘’Ma mère est partie.” in the most gentle way I could. “My mom has left.” I felt so much peace at that moment. I learned that witnessing first hand the passing of someone is not a frightening process. What is frightening is our own fear towards the realisation that we are faced with our own issues towards our own mortality. We truly do not live forever, yet we plan and do things like we are. Weird that… Anyway… I need a break. I am too full of emotions right now to write what I witnessed with my dad. He passed away on February 8. 2017 at precisely 5:15 p.m. ( Give or take 10 seconds or so.) I miss them both very much.

When I was around eleven, I remember having an intensely vivid dream. My Great Grandmother was standing on a set of stairs at her old weekend house, and I was standing at the bottom. My Great Grandmother died when I was seven. As a young child, I spent a significant amount of time visiting with both she and my unmarried Great Aunt. Every weekend after church my mother and I would go over to their old converted school house for lunch. At that point, it was just she and I since my father wouldn’t come back into the picture until I was around five. Money was extremely tight, and my Great Aunt, and Great Grandmother quietly supplemented my childhood with the treats and toys my mother wouldn’t have been able to provide otherwise. I have extremely fond memories of playing out on the front porch, and in the backyard where my aunt grew sunflowers and tomatoes during the summer. During the dream, I remember panicking over the fact that my Great Grandmother was dead. I wasn’t aware that I was dreaming, and the fact that she was now standing in front of me disturbed me to no end. I tried to get away and ran out onto the front porch, but she followed me. Eventually, I calmed down, and became really happy to see her. I don’t remember words, but I remember it being conveyed to me that everything was going to be alright. I didn’t really get what the message was about at the time, but once I acknowledged it she let me know that she needed to go. I remember being disappointed because she had just arrived, but she kept stressing to me that she had to leave. Then she stepped off the front porch, and she walked off down the dirt road through the woods that ran in front of the property. The road was never dirt while I was alive, but it was when my Great Aunt first purchased the house. A few months later, the dot-com crash of the early 2000’s happened, and my father lost his job. My family was in the middle of relocating between states, we had just sold our house, and we were suddenly left jobless and homeless. We ended up living in my Great Aunt’s house that year - the same one from my dream. About six months later, my dad found a new job, and we moved. Everything ended up being alright. I mentioned that dream a few weeks ago to my mother. My Great Aunt has since passed, and now my Grandmother is unwell. As the oldest grandchild, I’m the cousin with the most memories of the older generation. We were reminiscing, and my mom shared a story with me that she never has before. After my dad got that new job, we had to move cross-country from the northeast to the southwest. It was a huge culture shock and once again money was tight. I think my mom felt it the worst of all, because she had to move from the region she had grown up in, and leave her family and friends behind. One day, she was out shopping for food. While she was in the store, she came across some fun educational place mats. They weren’t fancy. Just the plastic covered kind geared towards kids. My Great Aunt and Great Grandmother were forever buying fun/educational odds and ends for the kids in the family. In fact, when I used to visit them on the weekends, trips to the local drugstore were always the highlight, because it meant I got to pick out some sort of cheap book or a new toy. That day in the grocery store, my mother seriously debated over whether or not to buy the place mats. They were exactly the type of thing my Great Aunt and Great Grandmother would have picked up, and it would have made her happy. But, eventually she decided not too. Money at the time was too tight after almost a year without regular income, and she couldn’t justify it. She finished shopping, left the store, and walked over to the car to put her groceries in the trunk. Sitting next to the car, there was an almost empty cart that hadn’t been there when she walked in. In it, there were exactly three place mats. One for me, one for my younger sister, and one for my younger brother. She quietly said thank you, put them in the car, and never shared with any of us how she had come by them. I remember coming home from school and seeing them sitting on the table. My mom seemed inordinately pleased, but at fourteen years old I wasn’t terribly impressed. Now it makes a lot more sense. A sign of something more, or just a strange series of coincidences and events? I don’t know. It’s not something I really give much thought to on a day to day basis, and I definitely don’t have any answers. But, its comforting to think about, and I’m happy that my mom shared her side of events with me.

I’m 65, and thus the oldest living member of my family. My relationship with my elders was troubled and often cold. I learned by experience that even though I didn’t much LIKE any of them nor feel close to them, it still felt like a terrible loss when they died. I’m not much of a worrier, yet I dread the very thought of either me OR my amazing wife having to survive the other. I know that I really cannot imagine now how I would react, but at present, I cannot even imagine how I would carry on, if it were me. But this story is about another loved one. I once lived on the Island of Maui; a place so beautiful it gets in your bloodstream and NEVER leaves you, no matter how long you stay away. Across the street from us lived a family with two young boys, about 9 and 11. The whole family were just a little “crooked” but I liked them anyway. They had a lot of cats, and the boys were constantly bugging me to “take a kitten, take a kitten.” I had been broke, unemployed and kind of beaten when I moved in. Don’t get me wrong, I’m definitely a “cat person.” I even speak the language fairly fluently, but our rental unit was a “no pets” place, much like most in that area. I basically talked my way in with the landlord, and I didn’t want to cause trouble. It meant much to me to keep my word, even to this skinflint slumlord. One Halloween, I was preparing for kids to come by trick-or-treating. I had my costume, my bag of candy (munching away, I was) and was stationed by the front door, waiting for the whole ritual to begin. “Ding-dong!” I went to the door, and there were the neighbor boys, dressed in home made costumes, holding bags filled with candy. I began my part, which was to compliment their costumes and give them some candy. Then I noticed that the younger one was holding out his hands, attempting to give ME something! I was thinking “this is weird,’ yet I still accepted what he had to offer. It was the tiniest little calico kitten I had ever seen. She was meowing, purring, and licking my hand. My heart melted, but I still said “no, we can’t take her. I want to keep my word, and I agreed to the no pets policy when I moved in. The kitten kept snuggling in my hands, and the little boys (lying little shits that they were) said “Please! You’ve just GOT to take her. We were trick-or-treating and some drunk guy gave her to us as a ‘treat.’ We can’t take her home, or our mom would KILL us!” I kept looking at the cat, falling hopelessly in love with her, and I finally relented. She moved in, and I named her “Fantasia.” A few months later, she got hit by a car, and I found her under the house (Most Hawaiian homes are on stilts.) I immediately began performing Reiki on her, pouring as much healing energy as I could muster into her. We then took her to the Vet. The X-Rays showed that her fractured hip had “mysteriously” aligned perfectly and was already beginning to knit! I explained my Reiki treatment to the Dr. and she just sort of smirked. Gee, it must be WONDERFUL to know everything like that. It must be such a burden. Anyway, NO, this is not the part of the story that deals with death yet. Time went on, she grew up into a very cranky little bitch-kitty. She acted like she hated everyone except me. But our bond was deep and I loved her greatly. Some years later, we moved to the mainland and brought her with us. She REALLY hated flying and driving, but we got through it. After some years of this, I was diagnosed with cancer. I began the chemo immediately, and all the usual horrors commenced. My hair fell out, I wasted away to just over half my weight, and I became very “dreamy.” Fantasia would NOT leave my side, not for a minute. I still have a photo of her laying on my back as I rested on my stomach, looking for all the world like those temple statues in Egypt where cats were Divine and guarded their temples. She regularly killed birds and mice and laid them at my feet. She prowled the house, keeping all the monsters and demons at bay. And, my dears, I got better! I am eternally grateful to say that I am still cancer-free now, 5 years later, with an excellent prognosis. Well, my sweet, crabby little kitty grew into an old girl of 12, and her vision began to fail. I could see she was in pain all the time, and I knew it would soon be time to say farewell and ease her on her way. She was suffering, and I will NEVER allow an animal to suffer, merely to spare my own feelings. So we made that dreaded trip to the Vet. I went in with her, and she stared into my eyes as they started the IV. They left me for a few minutes to “say goodbye,” then came back in and gave her the injection that brought her peace, finally. I watched the light in her eyes fade, flicker and go out. I watched the light lift from her little body and float away, and I felt her intense protective energy depart, once and for all. My Temple Guardian was dead. I wept bitter tears of grief. I was inconsolable for days, weeping and just feeling the terrible pain and loss of losing her. I realized then that I was actually weeping for ALL the loved ones I had lost, in this lifetime and before. I was weeping for my mother and my father. My grandmothers and grandfathers. My step parents, uncles and aunts who left me to grow old. I knew that I could not stand to maintain this intense level of grief much longer, and I began to look within for the same spiritual solutions that sustained me through my own brush with death. I spoke to my guardian angel and all the elemental spirits that love to come and play at my house. And finally, I wrote this song. I know it almost sounds silly to tell people “I wrote it because my cat died,” but that’s just the way it is. I will just mention that I now have an amazing Guardian Angel in the form of my wonderful little toy poodle service dog named Buddy. Buddy knows exactly what to do when I become severely depressed, and when I have a PTSD fugue, he immediately begins “grounding” me which cuts the episode short and calls me back into my body again, rather than traveling back to the horror that sparked the disorder. He keeps my soul healthy and is a being of Pure Unconditional Love. I know everybody says that about dogs, and it IS true, yet this little guy is truly something unique and special. I don’t actually believe he’s a dog. He’s not human either, as that would be an insult, but neither is he “just” a dog. I’ll share the lyrics to the song with you now. Please know it is copyrighted, and I hold all rights. I share it with you, and ask that you don’t take it as your own, or incorporate it into your own art. You have a song inside you as well; you don’t need to take mine, but you are welcome to experience it here. Goodbye, (C) 2013, all rights reserved, By Patrick Dieter and Joah Greengus (Chorus) Now you’re gone from this lifetime, you will never return I can still feel your touch, feel the lessons we learned You killed me, you healed me, you taught me to fly But I wish I could have told you Goodbye. (Verse) I heard the sad news, I just broke down and cried When they told me your worn out old body had died Though I’m crying right now in my pain and my grief My heart tells my soul there will soon be relief. (Chorus) Now you’re gone from this lifetime, you will never return I can still feel your touch, feel the lessons we learned You’re as real as any star in the sky Still I wish I could have told you Goodbye (Verse) You and I, we go back to a time before space We were playmates forever in that lost garden place See I know, that I Know that I KNOW you’re still here And that Knowing tells me I have nothing to fear (Refrain) Time after time tells me stories of old Heroes and villains and seekers of gold Swimming, then crawling, then walking, then flight The eternal progression from darkness to light The progression from darkness to light. (Chorus) Now you’re gone from this lifetime, you will never return I can still feel your touch, feel the lessons we learned You killed me, you healed me, you taught me to fly But I wish I could have told you Goodbye You’re as real as any star in the sky Still I wish I could have told you Goodbye. Peace and love to all. If you don’t believe in Angels and things, then you are welcome to your shrunken grey world. I will never understand how any intelligent person can say they “don’t believe” in something, merely because they’ve never experienced it, and then claim to be “scientific.” All true science starts with a sense of wonder, and the fond embrace of what you DON’T know. Anything else isn’t rigor, it’s just stubbornness.

My father dropped dead out of the blue one day when I was 14. Within an hour, my brother and I discovered our little finch, whom we’d named God, was dead in his cage. Although my father’s death was an inconvenient tragedy for all but me, I was able to disguise my relief by repeatedly claiming, “God is dead!”. But that ain’t nuthin compared to what happened when The Love of My Life died, 15 years later. Emily Fisher's answer to How did you meet the love of your life, whether or not you married him or her, or if it was reciprocated? For 2 years I’d been taking care of George in our island home, on Puget Sound. During his last 6 months I’d had to attach him to a machine for 12 hours a day, one which, at the time, had never before been used out of the hospital. I convinced the hospital to train me in its usage, so that George could go home to live out the rest of his life. I’ve written about this here before, in greater detail, but am too lazy to chase down links. (I’ve vowed to be more lazy in the new year, a resolution I’m bound to keep.) George’s son, Bruce (who later built my castle in the desert), had come to live with us for the end times. So he was around, but had an active social life. I’d gotten over my first woman, to whom I’d given both my heart and sanity Emily Fisher's answer to Have you ever been the subject of an artist’s portrait painting?, but she was still my best friend, and adored George, so she was around a fair amount in the final days when I’d turned that machine into a morphine pump, as those hadn’t yet been invented. I’d been having to shoot up George with large doses of morphine every 2 hours round the clock, and the extreme up and down of that leaves a lot to be desired. So now, through the machine, he was getting a steady stream of the stuff, which worked lots better. But eventually it got to the point where the only way George wasn’t in screaming agony was if I kept him just below the level of consciousness. Emily Fisher's answer to What is your favorite painting and why? At that point, my sister arrived for support. It was nice having Bruce, my sister, and First Woman around, though it was also disturbing to suddenly have so little to do, with George now unconscious 24/7. The day came that I could tell would be George’s last. His breathing had gotten wonky and sporadic. I hadn’t a clue how much time he might have, but could sense it was the end. This telltale breathing business had begun after Bruce had taken off for the day, and since it was long before cell phones, I was unable to track him down, to tell him to get his ass home. First Woman, my sister and I sat around George’s bed, involuntarily holding our breath when George held his, until the length of time he did that became too great and we had to give it up. Increasingly, the lengthening cessation of breath appeared to be the end, but then he’d snork out a new one and the process would start over. After a few rounds of this, I began to giggle, which surprised Woman and my sister until I explained why. George was a lifelong big cold water swimmer, even had these rare things deep in his ears that looked like tiny seals’ ears, something mostly only seen in the ears of deep sea divers. And he could hold his breath an absurd amount of time. When the kids were little, he’d scare them (and me) by staying submerged in the ocean for far too long a time. It didn’t matter that we knew how long he could hold his breath — this time, obviously something had gone wrong! Then up he’d pop. Against all reason, he’d even play this trick on us in the bathtub. Of course common sense told us he wasn’t drowning in the bathtub, but no! commoner sense told us humans simply cannot hold their breath that long! It was downright freaky. And so, with George now acting as though each breath was his last, then popping up again, I couldn’t help being reminded of his old trick, and at that moment I realized I could stop worrying about being unable to contact Bruce, that there was no way George was going to die before Bruce’s return. But still, the length between breaths was getting ridiculously long, and my common sense was beginning to backfire the same way it used to with the bathtub trick. Finally, Bruce showed up. Having been gone all day, he was somewhat shocked to see George’s condition. Before he had time to adjust, I clued him in on the old trick George was playing on us. The degree of glee with which I imparted this information to Bruce was nearly as disturbing to him as George’s last breaths, but eventually he, too, caught the gory rhythm and began to giggle/gasp in relief each time a new breath shot out. Every part of George’s illness/dying process was magnificent, which was what had added to me knowing he wouldn’t die before Bruce returned. In that same way, the breathing issue stopped progressing when Bruce showed up. It was as though he had to wait for Bruce to catch up before he continued on his journey. But Bruce did catch up, and then, suddenly, ages passed between breaths, and our eyes widened in various forms of disbelief. It was so long between breaths, that Woman and my sister would think it was over, but Bruce and I suspected a trick. I noticed that during those absurdly long periods of no breathing, there was a vein pounding powerfully in George’s neck. By then I was in the bed with him, holding his top half in my lap. I could feel that vein pounding. I was singing to him, humming to him, rocking him, telling him we were all here and it was okay to go, that Bruce and I would be fine. And then one time, his breath stopped for the by then expected ridiculously long stretch while the neck vein continued to beat. Until it didn’t. That vein quit marking passage, we let out a collective sigh, and at that moment the sound of a large crystal bell chimed in the room. There was nothing either inside or outside the house that could have made that sound, a sound we all admitted we’d never heard before but could instantly recognize as a loud crystal bell. Bruce immediately started yelping, “What was that? What was THAT???” to which I automatically replied, “Sounds to me like an angel just got his wings!”. “No, really, what was that?” “I’m giving you the best answer I’ve got! That’s what it sounded like to me!” “But what WAS it?” Bruce demanded. We all agreed we’d heard the same thing, though none had what could be called a logical explanation. When the impossible happens, we draw our own conclusions.

Yes I have. And this will probably piss off people like Laura Lingle, but I am not embarrassed to talk about what I saw. First a bit of background. My parents were from India, although I was born and brought up for most of my life in England. As most people might know, India is an incredibly spiritual place, in the sense that huge swathes of the population believe in deities, the soul and re-incarnation. In the western world, a lot of people simply think religious people are gullible loons who will believe anything. When one sees the murder and bloodshed attributed to religious nutters, I tend to agree. Now growing up in England, I believe I have a healthy amount of scepticism about ‘other worldly’ happenings and always find myself looking for rational explanations for ‘miracles’ and other circumstances that some people may try and pass off as divine intervention. However, what I am about to describe has no scientific explanation that I am aware of. For the benefit of the casual reader, a certain group of religious people who shall remain nameless for now, firmly believe that reciting god’s name daily puts them in closer touch to the almighty. The soul is an eternal entity and gets the chance to occupy the human form only once it has passed through 8.4 million other species. So getting the chance to be a human is a pretty rare thing. Only from the human form does the soul have the opportunity to escape the cycle of birth/death (re-incarnation) and become one with the lord through good deeds, meditation and good karma. These people live their lives in simple ways, with particular attention paid to daily meditation and prayers. Within the community it is a well known fact that the members who follow their religious regimes closely are able to predict when their time is up a few weeks in advance. Bear in mind, often these are perfectly healthy people, with no terminal illness or other life threatening ailment. There are also accounts of souls being escorted ‘off this world’ by ‘higher’ beings to go join with the almighty. These beings have been described as being identifiable as departed religious leaders. Their presence is always described as being accompanied by bright white lights. With that background out of the way, here’s what I experienced. My wife’s granddad was a very religious man. He meditated daily and led a simple life. A few weeks before his death, he started to tell family around him that his time was near. He had no illness and as often happens, people around him just pass it off and say, there’s nothing wrong with you, you’re gonna be around for a while yet. So it’s Friday and it’s late at night, perhaps nearly 1am and I’m on my computer watching videos online. All of a sudden from behind me and to the right, I sense a bright white light. I turn towards it and sense two souls, my wife’s granddad and another. No words are spoken but I sense their desire to leave with the thought “there’s nothing to be found here”. As quickly as it had appeared, the light disappears and it’s just me in the room again. Soon after, tired, I shut down and go upstairs to go to sleep, thinking nothing more of it. Now this is the bit that makes my hair stand on end even as I type this nearly 10 years later. At that point in time, my wife’s granddad was still alive as far as we knew. However, before 6am that morning, we receive a phone call from my father-in-law saying that they’d gone into granddad’s room to check on him as he wasn’t up early as usual and they found he’d passed away sometime during the night in his sleep. They’d called an ambulance, but all they could do was confirm he was no longer with us. Now it’s clear there’s no way to reproduce this exact scenario and even if there was, would any modern instrument be able to detect and record any such happenings? I don't know. Maybe, maybe not. The whole thing was so brief that I didn’t even have time to think I could have tried to record it with my phone, so all I have is the memory. Which is why stuff like this always gets dismissed as anecdotal mumbo jumbo. Make of it what you will.

Yes, when my father died I had to go down to the morgue to identify him. They didn’t realize He had a relative who lived in town which is why He was in the morgue and no one had called me when He died in the hospital. I had just moved to California. Anyway, so there I was in the morgue with my dad who I hadn’t seen since I was 7. I was now in my thirties. He looked very different than when I saw him at seven. As a little girl he looked just like Carey Grant or Frank Sinatra in my little girl eyes. But now, he was huge in the stomach and looked like a cross between Paul Bunyan and a ‘bum’ I had known as a child. (I don’t use the word bum in a derogatory sense, but that’s the word I used for this adult person I knew when I was around 7). Anyway, I knew it was him though because of his facial features and he had a worried brow denoted by three worry lines right between his eyes. He had always had that from as long as I remembered him- like he always carried around a permanent concern that he could never figure out. When I saw him I cried. And though I was afraid everyone outside that door was going to hear me and think I was mentally ill (even I thought maybe it was a sign I was mentally ill!), I cried with tears gushing down my face and everything I had ever wanted to say to my dad came gushing out. I told him how much I loved him, how much I admired him, how much I didn’t ever blame him for anything, how much I had thought about him over the years, that our bond of love had never been broken. I held his hand and kept my head on his chest. I had eternal tears. I prayed for him. A twinge of guilt swept through me when I prayed in the voice of my minister who warned me that it was a grave sin to pray for the dead. I decided instantly if God was going to put me in hell for praying for the dead then he couldn’t be a good God. I kept praying. I knew I was probably the only one who would pray for him. I was filled with compassion, love, sadness, regret, more sadness. Then all of the sudden his whole body shifted. His arm moved like he was sleeping. I freaked out. Was he really dead? Did they make a mistake? I was afraid to tell anyone thinking they would call me delusional and lock me up. I googled it - actually I don’t think there was google back then- it was Netscape- but I discovered that this was ‘common’ - nerves are still alive even after the person is declared deceased. But back then this was remarkable to me. Just as remarkable, that same day, I was going home on the bus and I sat down, heavy with grief in the first seat I saw in the back of the bus, at first not noticing the person next to me. Then I looked up, into his face. The exact same face of the person, my dad, as he was in the morgue. Same body too. My eyes went big as saucers. I wanted to tell him but didn’t know how. I stayed silent. But somehow this remarkable event made me feel hope and brought me a sense of peace. This same kind of thing - seeing a person who looked like my relative in appearance, demeanor and essence also happened when my Uncle and Mom died too but I don’t wish to write about them right now.

My husband’s mother, aged 100 + two or three months, played cards one evening, went to bed as usual, but a few hours later the retirement home staff called to tell us that she had slipped from sleep into a coma and was unlikely to wake from it or live for very long. My husband and his brother sat with her until past noon, when they went to get something to eat. I took over for them for the interim. She was still unresponsive, breathing heavy, slow breaths. Members of the nursing staff came to stand around the bed, murmuring among themselves about how warmly she had impressed them in her time there. She died about forty minutes later. I’d been sitting by the bed holding her hand, feeling how hot her skin was — she had probably died, as many old people do, of a urinary tract infection, which meant there was a high fever involved. When they’d straightened everything up after and I came back inside the room, I saw that the nurses tied a hand towel around her face to keep her jaw from gaping, so that she seemed to be asleep. I sat down again to wait for her sons to come back, and I took her hand again. I’d been out of the room for about ten minutes, but her skin was just as hot as it had been before she died. I remember thinking, she’s not here any more, or breathing, but her body is still responding to its infection with fever, which is caused by antibodies in the blood fighting the invasion of the organisms attacking the body’s systems. It was the first time I’d ever thought of the body, emptied of its spirit, still “living” in very basic ways, still trying to defend itself from a death that had already happened. The body and the soul (if you believe in the soul, which I do although I’m not religious) had been together so long that we all, including my mother-in-law, saw them as one being — but now I saw that the body was a being in its own right, fighting like mad not to succumb to a death that had already happened, while the soul had quietly detached itself and flown somewhere else. I’ve had an odd, almost affectionate sympathy for my own body ever since (it’s 77+ years old now), and I look after it as much as I can. My mother-in-law and I were never that close, for various reasons, but that death-watch feels like some kind of gift she made to me, a final gesture of good will. I’m grateful to have it.

I’m going to go slightly off topic to answer this but still I think you’ll find it interesting. I hope… Having been dead once and close a few times, I have noticed one thing that happens. People go AWOL. Friends, family, others. And I’ve researched this by asking others about their experiences as well and resoundingly the answer is the same for those that have actually died - and come back. At the time when you actually need that human connection and for someone to just ask whether you’re okay or not - this is the last thing that seems to happen. Why? I don’t know. Maybe it’s too much for people to deal with but when it happened to me for the first time (brief story below) there was only one person who asked me whether I was okay or not. So here’s the short story: I have asthma. Well, I had asthma. It seems to have left me alone for a decade or two… One night I woke, unable to breathe at 1am in the morning. I grabbed the car keys and drove around a mile, without breathing, to the hospital, dumped the car right outside the A&E door, walked through it into the waiting room. Two nurses saw me and asked me what was wrong. I had just enough oxygen left in me to answer “asthma” and promptly collapsed on the floor and lost control of ‘bodily functions’. I was in intensive care for about a week before making it onto ward and when I did some doctor brought a group of student doctors around. “Here’s the man who sees it fit to park his car right outside the door of the A&E!” he announced to the group. I waited for him to finish his rant before indicating to the group that if I hadn’t of done that then he wouldn’t be there chastising me because I would’ve been dead and had actually died. When I went back to work everyone trod on eggshells around me. It was only my boss - out of everyone I knew, including my parents - who asked me, not as my boss, but just from one human to another: “Are you okay?” My answer was, no, I’m not - but I think I will be. And I only thought I would be in that instant after he actually asked me. But because someone actually cared enough to ask, that made the difference I needed and after that I went from strength to strength - personally, professionally, the works. Sometimes all you need is just that one person with the right words at the right time for you to pivot from falling down the mountain to turning and making your way back up it. Years later - two decades later in fact - I ran into him online and thanked him again. I will remember that, as I have to this day, forever.

I worked for many years as a geriatric nursing assistant and witnessed many people die, also nursed many through the dying process, there is no certain way of death, some people collapse and die very quickly through heart attack or a lung embolism, for e.g….while others die naturally of old age, which usually follows a pattern which can be observed in most people whose lives are coming to an end, this is not a sudden death, but one that can take days or even weeks, starting with losing their appetite and refusing at some point even water to slowly becoming unresponsive, followed by laboured breathing which culminates in stoke Cheyne breathing until the person passes away…..however once death has occurred there is a definite and immediate change in the body, almost as if a light has simply gone out, you can actually see this light leave a dying persons eyes, there is a definite and profound sense of a spirit leaving this body and leaving behind an empty shell….this is what I call the life force…it leaves …..but nevertheless there is a sense of it being still there for some time, just not attached to this body!. . This is my experience with every person I saw die and I am convinced that we have a separate spirit, which is the real us and which goes on after the body dies, therefor nobody ever really dies…I think this is a very comforting thing….something else I experienced was after the death of my sister at the age of 41 , I was utterly distraught at her passing, though I knew she could die any time as she had a terminal renal illness, nevertheless I could not stop crying and was very sad and missed her horribly, we had been very close, then one night, a few weeks after she died I had such a vivid dream it seemed absolutely real….I was crying, sobbing really and she came to me, stood before me and said very clearly… " stop crying now, im ok, I'm happy now" …..I woke up feeling certain that she had really been here and said this to me!!…. the strange thing is I have heard of so many people who have had exactly this same dream after someone they loved died so I do believe this was her way of comforting me and that this is something real and not just imagined in someones grief.

I wasn’t in his presence when he transitioned, but I believe he visited me in a dream shortly thereafter. Here’s the story: For months, I used to see a homeless man wandering one of the busy streets in my neighborhood. I was always in a car when I’d pass him, but I always had an inexplicable feeling of wanting to meet him. I’d never felt that way towards anyone before or since. One day, I was taking a walk down a side street and saw him walking about a half block ahead of me. I picked up my pace and literally felt a sense of joy that I was finally getting the chance to meet him. When I caught up to him, I introduced myself, found out his name was Steve and we stood in the street talking for about an hour. We formed an instant friendship as he told me all about his life, how he’d ended up homeless due to alcoholism and a few stories about his life on the streets. He wasn’t sad about his life at all, but took everything in stride. He’d been in the neighborhood for years and told me there were several people, including business owners and a few police officers, who looked out for him. He wasn’t one to beg, but he did accept meals from people who offered, as well as warm clothes, etc. To pay for his alcohol, he collected recyclables and took them to a nearby facility where he traded them for cash. I joined the ranks of people who looked out for him and considered him a friend. He had a humble spirit, was very easy to talk to and always had a pleasant disposition. When I could find him, I’d give him a home cooked meal, clean clothes and even took him for breakfast at a nearby cafe where everyone was very kind to him despite the way he looked and smelled. After a few months of getting to know him, I decided to track his family down with his permission. His mom had already passed away and his dad, as far as he knew, was still alive, but had become what he described as a holier-than-thou Christian. Soon after his dad overcame his own alcoholism, Steve said he’d kicked him and his siblings (who also had addiction issues) out of the family home following his mother’s death. Steve had a son, but didn’t know where he was and had lost touch with his siblings long ago. Researching all of their names online led me to his sister and brother-in-law who were also still in touch with one of his brothers. Because they’d all struggled with alcoholism and were clean at that time, they were elated to hear he was still alive, but also very worried about bringing him into their homes because they didn’t want to be influenced by his drinking and didn’t want their children around it. I should add that Steve was also adamant about not quitting because he was afraid of the physical pain of detoxing. He’d almost done it once while in jail for a few days and he said it almost killed him. Content with his life the way it was, he wasn’t anxious to try quitting again. Anyway, his brother-in-law (who was also in recovery and had a very rough life when he was addicted, but had been helped by someone else in the past) spearheaded a trip to our city to at least meet up with him, reunite him with his siblings, and talk to him about getting cleaned up and possibly moving in with his family. We met at a local restaurant where I excused myself after the initial greetings were out of the way, just to give them privacy and time to talk. I still remember how nervous he was and him asking me if I was going to come back and get him (we were literally on the street he walked every day, so it wasn’t that he needed a ride, he was just nervous and didn’t want me to leave him alone). Here’s a photo from that day:  Long story short, all were happy to be reunited and his sister offered to take him home with her if he’d agree to rehab. He thanked her for her kind offer, but in no uncertain terms told his family that he was ok with living in the streets and that while he knew he should quit drinking, he was afraid to try. They left town agreeing to keep in touch with him through me, which they did. They often sent him letters, pictures and calling cards through the mail of which he was always happy to recieve. The last time I saw him, I’d had a letter in my car for days to give to him but hadn’t seen him walking the street where I normally did. I figured he’d been picked up by the police or maybe in the hospital (which happened from time to time) and that he’d turn up again soon. One night, I was turning the corner to my house and noticed him walking across a dark parking lot. I was exhausted, but made a U-turn to give him his mail. When I did, he got very serious for a moment, looked me in the eyes and said, “I really want to thank you for what you’ve done for me and for helping me maintain contact with my family.” I instantly felt a little ashamed because I’d been so tired I’d honestly thought about not stopping and just giving him his mail on another day. And here he was thnking me for my kindness, not knowing I’d just forced myself to make that U. A short while after that, I hadn’t seen him for several days, but had a very realistic dream. In it, I was in front of my mother’s house and there was a party going on inside. Steve walked up and, instead of the tattered clothes he usually wore, he was dressed in a buttoned down denimn shirt with a vest, was clean shaven, his blue eyes were sparkling and his formerly rotten teeth were a bright white. I touched his chest to welcome him to the party and he smiled and said he’d just stopped by to thank me for my friendship and all I’d done for him. I told him he was very welcome and I encouraged him to go inside, have some food and join the party. The last thing I remember about the dream is him sitting in a chair in the corner of my mom’s living room, next to a lamp with a bottle in his hand smiling from ear to ear. The next day, my husband and I were traveling down the street where we always saw him and I asked my husband had he seen him lately to which he replied he had not. I told him about the dream and said that I think he may have passed on. We didn’t talk anymore about it (my husband thinks I’m crazy when I say things like that, so the silence was normal, lol), but just went on about our day. A day or two later, his brother-in-law called me. Steve’s body had been found a couple of days before in front of a local business where he’d apparently passed away in his sleep. Steve had given a liquor store owner his family’s phone number to call in case of emergency and the store’s owner had given it to the police after his body had been discovered next door to the liquor store. In my heart of hearts, I know my friend is doing well, he is healthy and he is content in his new life. I’m grateful he thought enough of me to come say a final goodbye.

I’ve been at someone’s bedside twice when their life support was turned off and they passed away. The first time was a disabled teenage boy that I took care of. He survived almost six hours after they turned off his life support. But once his heart stopped, he had spasms for at least 5 minutes afterward. The doctor said that the spasms were normal reflexes as the inner parts of the brain stem send signals that they need more oxygen. I was glad I had that experience with him, because it prepared me for that when it happened with my father ten years later. My mother did not want to be at my father’s side when they turned off his life support and he passed. She was too distraught to see it, which was a good thing, because he also had spasms for a few minutes. It’s not something you want to see a loved one go through. But, by the time you get to the “turn off the life support” part of the process, you’ve already seen your loved one go through a lot of things, right? Anyway, another thing I found interesting in both cases was how they got the body out of the ICU. It was just something I never thought about before, but you don’t exactly want to wheel a dead body, even if it was covered by a sheet, past the beds of very sick people and their loved ones. So at both hospitals they had a special gurney with tall curtains around it for getting the body through the rest of the hospital on the way to the morgue. If you didn’t know what it was, you’d probably think it was a food delivery. It was designed specifically to not look obvious. I thought it was very considerate for them to think about that. Also related, the teenager had several implanted medical devices, some of which had low battery alarms. The hospital had the foresight to turn off the alarms before they turned off the life support, so that the low battery alarms wouldn’t beep in his grave.

One day, a year or so after my teenage daughter "broke up" with a boy whom we had gotten to know, (his mom had been diagnosed with cancer months before) I had a very strong feeling to contact him on Facebook and just ask how he had been doing. He answered me immediately and said, my mom is dying. I told him that I knew she was sick, and that's why I was checking on him. He said no... right now he is in the hospice room with her and her breathing has changed and he thought she was gone. I asked him what he wanted to do, and he said he didn't want to leave her. I told him it would be OK if he sat with her as long as he wanted, and when he was done he should go get the hospice staff and they would take care of her from there . This was being done via Facebook messenger, and we sat quietly for about 5 to 10 minutes, when he said her hand was cold and he was ready to go. I told him let me know if there was anything I could do for him, and the next time I heard from him it was regarding the funeral. On the day of the funeral my daughter and I were preparing to go and I stopped on the way to look for a card or something I could write on to share our condolences. While standing in the card section I became frustrated I didn't like anything that I saw, I decided a card didn't feel right and I just wouldn't do it... but on the way out I passed the candy section and felt a strong sense that I should buy some Skittles. When arriving at the funeral and passing through the line with this young man and his brothers I gave him the skittles and said, “dude I brought you a rainbow” The funeral service was lovely, his mother knew she was dying and planned most of it herself right down to the music. As the services ended they asked us all to enjoy her favorite song as we proceed out of the church. My heart and my spirits were lifted immediately when the song started, it was "somewhere over the rainbow" As I pass the boys again on the way out we all hugged and I made sure they knew that that message was from their mother, I didn't even know her, but that message was from her! At her exact moment of passing she somehow got into my psyche so I contacted her boy and virtually held his hand as she left. Then she made sure I brought him a message of hope, directly from her.

When my aunt was dying of cancer, she had hospice care at home. I was the only one taking care of her. The hospice nurses would check on her once a day, but I was the only one administering to her. Dr. gave me a bottle of morphine as said “as needed.” As she grew closer to death, she didn’t seem to need the morphine, so I didn’t give her any. However, she was still ‘in and out;’ not quite in a coma, but not quite here either. I sat by her side that entire night, lights dimmed, just me and her. She was mumbling and talking. Some of the words I could make out, some I couldn’t. I heard her talk to her mother (I heard the word ‘Ma’) and I heard her talk to several other people. I guess because of that, I got the feeling that there were many spirits in the room. At one point, I even smelled pipe tobacco, which made no sense to me until well after her death, I remembered my grandfather (her father) smoked a pipe. I was only a child when he died. When she was well, I remember her telling me that she had a childhood friend named ‘Lottie.’ One very clear sentence I heard was “Wait a minute, Lottie. I’m coming. Just wait a minute.” It was then that I told her it was o.k. to leave; that I would be o.k. She was still mumbling and even laughed a few times. Then, after sitting awhile, I had to go the bathroom. Five steps down the hall (at home remember), a quick pee and back to the bedroom. She was gone. She waited until I had left before she ‘let go.’ It was almost impossible to believe - I was gone all of five seconds. After thinking about it, I thought that she stayed because I was there - she was staying for me. But when I went to the bathroom, she left her body. My Aunt was quite the lady in life and a lady always knows when to leave the room.

As my Mom-in-law aged, she was put in a nursing home, and eventually required certain medications. One Wednesday, my sister-in-law called and said that Meem (nickname) was fighting her caretakers when they tried to give her the medications, and my sister-in-law wanted to confer with her brother (my husband) as to what should be done about the situation. I said to her that it was none of my business, but that I felt that Meem was telling everyone what she wanted….. she was ready to go “home”. That weekend my husband and his sister met up to put Meem’s affairs in order and to visit her (two hours north of where we lived). Hubby came back home and then headed north again the next day. That Tuesday morning I had one of the dogs that we showed in agility trotting on the treadmill in what I call our “exercise room”. I was sitting in a chair at the front of the treadmill and next to some shelving across from the treadmill. We have a small TV there (plus a lot of other junk), and every Tuesday morning there were two of those psychic shows on TV, back-to-back… one at 10:00 am and the other at 10:30 am. When the commercials came on between the two shows at 10:30, I looked down at my feet and saw a CD sitting there that was labeled “Meem’s Retirement Party.” I started listening to the CD, and it sounded like Meem was in a receiving line as her friends and fellow teachers came to wish her well in her retirement. Later that afternoon my husband came back home, and he sadly told me that his mother had died that morning. I quickly asked him what time she had died, and he responded, “10:30 am”. (My hair still stands on end when I think of this!) I spent the rest of that day trying to figure out WHY I had mysteriously found that particular CD that morning at that particular time, and eventually I went to bed still thinking about it. Suddenly it was as if Meem was standing next to my bed as I heard her talking in that retirement party receiving line to her friends and fellow teachers as she said, “Thank you. Thank you so very much!”

This is a physiological description of my father’s death: A couple of years ago, on the morning of Christmas Eve, we were staying at my parents when my dad collapsed on the driveway outside while carrying in groceries. My husband managed to get him inside and into his favourite chair. He was clammy and grey and breathing hard. I offered him gingerale as we’d all had the stomach flu leading up to Christmas and I thought maybe he was having low blood sugar. He said “that would be lovely”, turned to me and smile and then suddenly his arms shot out in front of him and his legs (which were elevated) started to convulse as well. He started hyperventilating and so I called my mom and then called for an ambulance. She got him calmed down several times while sitting in the chair, but while my husband was out of the room and while I was on the phone with the 911 dispatcher, my mom saw a flash of light behind my fathers eyes and then they went dull. A few minutes later, as he appeared to be breathing, his face flushed red now, we moved him onto the ground as per the instructions from the dispatcher. I ran upstairs to get dressed and when I came down, he appeared to be staring blankly ahead and I then heard him burp up air. Later I realized that he had been dead at this point and that was the air leaving his lungs. As for the flash of light, however, I have googled it and asked about it, but I’ve never found an answer, nor have I ever found anyone else who has experienced it. We never did find out what he died of either. He had just been to the doctor who had declared him in excellent health, though he was in the mid stages of dementia.
