I have a good friend who's a nurse. She told me the story: she wore a tiny cross pin next to her name tag. She was assigned to a Jewish couple, the husband lying in bed dying. The wife looked at her name tag and said: “I see you're a Christian. Don't you dare say anything about God! Don't pray either!” My friend said she wouldn't. The husband was laying unconscious slightly propped up in the bed, tucked in neatly with the sheet, his hands resting at his sides on top of the sheet. Suddenly he sat up straight and started beating the sheets with his hands, yelling, “put out the fire put out the fire!” He then fell back, gasped and died. My friend was horrified. The wife turned to her and said, what just happened?! My friend the nurse could not answer, although she knew what had happened.

This was the most bizarre situation I had ever witnessed when someone died. I was a staff RN in an Emergency Department and late one night a young man was brought in by EMS with a history of gastro intestinal bleeding of long duration. That evening he had collapsed and EMS was called. Upon arrival life support measures were instituted immediately including CPR, fluid resuscitation, intubation, medications, etc., the entire ACLS protocol. If you have never witnessed a code you may not know that the patient is totally stripped of all clothing to facilitate assessment and medical intervention. After an inordinate amount of time spent attempting resuscitation the physician pronounced him dead. At that point I had been doing chest compressions and ceased at the time the physican terminated the efforts and pronounced him dead. It was at that moment the man ejaculated! No, a catheter had not been placed because his circulating blood volume was so little, the staff was busily attempting IV access, peripherally and centrally and had difficulty doing so. He was essentially volume depleted. I had never witnessed this before and neither had any of the other staff members. It was one of those things that you witness as a staff member in an Emergency Department and you just shrug your shoulders and think, well, I’ve seen it all….until the next bizarre case that you haven’t seen occurs.

A few years ago, my greatgrandmother was diagnosed with pancreas cancer. This particular type of cancer doesn’t bother a person much in the first stages and therefore death often follows very quickly after the diagnosis. Needless to say, it was a weird, rollercoaster period for our family. When I visited her in the hospital, she broke down in tears saying “I thought I’d never see you or Rune (my 2 year old boy) again, I thought you were gonna be afraid of me”. I reassured her that nothing in this world could make me so scared that I wouldn’t want to see her. Heck, this was a woman who had been there for me when my parents had to work and other relatives were to busy to look after me. So after this she pulled herself together and said: “you know son, the weirdest thing is KNOWING. I mean knowing that in a short period of time I won’t be here anymore, knowing that I won’t get to see Rune growing up… So to lighten the mood a bit, I responded: “well you know, you don’t know that for sure…” Being a woman who had gone through a lot in her life, without ever getting help from a divine creature, she looked at me very sceptic and said: “you have got to be kidding me!” I said: “well we just don’t know, do we? But hey, I guess you will know shortly. So let’s make a deal, if there’s an afterlife, you give me a sign on the first of the month after your passing. But not some bullshit the wind blew when I was thinking of you kinda thing. Something that is really unusual. She smiled and said: “You silly boy, you have always been able to make me smile. You know what? If possible I”ll scare the living hell out of you.” A few days later she fell into a coma, so this turned out to be our last conversation. She eventually died on July 11 and at the time I didn’t think about the deal much. She was an 88 year old woman, so I mourned her for a couple of days and then went back to my daily routines. So I was at work, doing very normal stuff, when one of my colleagues came to me and said: “It’s awfully hot today, can’t we do something about it?” Being a teamleader I had to come up with some solution to keep everyone motivated but I knew that turning up the airco wouldn’t help much. We were in a full window office with the sun shining all afternoon at it and a high airco would bother some people who had gotten headaches before from using the airco too long. I told one of my more experienced team members about the pickle I was in and he said not to worry, I have the solution, just trust me. So one hour later we had an ice cream truck in the middle of the factory, where it was the coolest. We all took a break there and everybody was just happy and enjoying these delicious refreshments. When I went to the ice cream guy to ask him what we owed him, he said: “don’t worry my friend, it’s all been taking care of.” Later that afternoon I was finishing some paper work after everyone had left, looked at the calendar and saw a huge 1 on it. Sure enough, it was August 1 and I immediately remembered ( of better yet, felt) the deal me and my greatgrandmother had made. There were no such events in the following, nor did we ever have ice cream at work. I understand that some of you will look at this story and say it is a coincidence. Perhaps that my subconscience was more aware of special things happening on the first and that on the second or third also something unusual happened without me even noticing. But at that time and every time I tell this story it makes me feel safe and looked after. So even if it is not a sign from the other side, I will settle for the good feeling it gives me.

My wife used to tell me of night table drawer handles flickering, and was convinced our house was haunted for a time. I thought she was nuts of course. But my wife is one of those super emphatic people who can instantly sense others emotions, and maybe other stuff? I’m ex-military, ethnic German, and an engineer. I don’t have an irrational bone in my body, and could probably explain away every flickering light as an air conditioner kicking on next door causing a power surge, (engineers call this line regulation) every sudden whoosh of air as the building ventilation fan kicking on, and every “puff of smoke” as clouding of your eyes by tears, something logical and rational. I don’t have any sense of the afterlife, dying just plain sucks, and if I can’t measure it, it’s not real. My point is, all these death experiences people talk of, and some may sneer at… Well maybe some are imaginary, grieving people definitely reach out for hope, and may interpret the normal in supernatural ways. Then again, maybe you need an open, emphatic mind to be even able to sense or detect these things, and maybe I’m poorer for lacking this? Most of the world’s scientists are rational, physical world thinkers, quick to explain away delusions of deeply grieving minds, especially to explain away hallucinogenic delusions from oxygen starved dying brains. Skin turning grey after death is tissue sucking the last remaining oxygen out of blood cells (turning blood from red to blue), or cheeks flushing red caused by sudden stoppage of the heart pumping. I see symptoms of a stopped heart, someone else sees glowing radiance from heaven. Are they delusionally ignorant, or do I just have an overly analytical closed mind? I don’t know, but I think people are happier if they believe something that may or may not be real.

For short, what I’ve witnessed is that as soon as a person dies, they become important to people around them, no matter their relationships or closeness to said persons. A couple days ago, a girl I went to elementary school with died from a heart attack. She was only 18. But the thing I noticed is that, when I had heard absolutely nothing, or even thought about her, for years, suddenly she was everywhere. All upon my newsfeed, people where sharing pictures and videos of her, claiming they missed her so much, they admired her so much, and that she was such a nice, lovely person, when some of them, I’m sure hadn’t heard about her in years, either (I’m not saying it’s bad at all, but I’ll get my point across further along the post). Similarly, a woman who used to work at my college died about a month ago. When she was alive, people would always criticize her, claiming she was mean and corrupt and disrespectful. Rarely did I hear people complimenting her or saying nice things about her. But then she died. Suddenly she was on everyone’s mouths, but this time most people said she was such a beautiful soul, such a kind woman, who left us too soon (except the rare people who actually hated her so much, they would say mean things such as “she had it coming.”) There’s many more examples, but I think these two demonstrate well enough what I’m trying to say. My point is that it seems to me that, when you’re alive, people either don’t care about you, or even openly dislike you, but as soon as you die, everyone seems to cherish you, miss you, and have you in their hearts. For one part, it’s nice that people at least respect your memory, and have you in their thoughts, but for the other, isn’t it sad that we must die in order for people to finally like us?

I lost my lovely father this past June 26th. He was 91 years old and finally succumbed to cancer. It was some 4 years after my Mother, Peggy—and the woman he truly loved and desperately missed—had passed away. My wife and I were driving when the call from my sister came in: “Dad’s gone.” I live in another country so I was unable to be there at that moment, but fortunately she was there and he wasn’t alone. Although it wasn’t unexpected news, it was of course, devastating. So I turned the truck into a side street and parked as soon as I could, so that I could talk properly with my sister. I have never been down that street before. As we were talking and agreeing that my father was ‘in a better place and with our Mum’, my wife tapped me on the shoulder and pointed to the house that we’d parked outside. It was a modest house, nothing fancy, but it was pretty and well maintained, with a short, brick path leading to the front door. Across the front porch was a large, curved sign, naming the house—obviously a great source of pride to the owner. It said: “Peggy’s Place”. Clearly my Dad was trying to tell me that he was finally at home with my Mum, and they had found peace. But that’s not quite all. The following morning I awoke a little early for some reason and just stayed there lying in bed for a moment or two to gather my thoughts. I was very sad at the loss of my father the afternoon before and I resolved that I would always remember that sad day of June 26th. So I turned and looked at my bedside digital clock. Guess what time it was? 06:26. Miss you Dad. God bless.

My first wife died at age 40 as I performed CPR. This was during the aftermath of a blizzard and it took the ambulance about 45 minutes to arrive. While doing CPR for this time, I tried to talk to her, thinking that she could surely hear me and be rallied, or at least be comforted if she realized what was happening. When the ambulance arrived the EMTs hooked up an instrument which showed a weak pulse in time with the chest compressions which I was still applying. They had me stop briefly and the instrument continued to show a weak regular beat. We got her into the ambulance and with the traffic assistance of all the on duty police (members of my own police agency) got her to the hospital despite the road conditions. During the trip I applied the breathing bag to my wife while one of the EMTs continued with chest compressions. I overheard the driving EMT on the radio with the ED doctor and could tell that the doctor did not believe there was any chance she would survive. The doctor called her death shortly after we arrived. I asked for privacy with her and, thinking and hoping that her spirit could still hear me, talked with her for another hour as she lay on the gurney with all kinds of equipment showing the efforts they made to revive her during that last few minutes before her “official” death. I admit that I'm talking all about me, not her. I didn't see any objective evidence that she heard me and that her spirit was still present. But I did everything I could and I do harbor hope (now 24 years later) that she was comforted.

Sixteen years ago, my brother and I got a call from my mother, telling us that my father was being rushed to the hospital. He had been quite sick for a few years, so this wasn't the first time he ended up in the hospital. For some reason, while driving in the car with my brother, we both felt like this time was different. Once we found our mom, we were escorted to a room where my dad was. We were told that he was dying and he would probably only have a few more hours. We sat there quietly - listening to all of sounds that were coming from the numerous machines that my father was hooked up to. All of a sudden, my mother said “Oh my G-d, look at daddy!” The most bizarre and unexplainable thing happened (right BEFORE my father died). We looked at my dad and we all saw it - his skin colour changed from extremely pale to a vibrant, healthy looking colour. He suddenly looked AMAZING! He looked like my “daddy” from my childhood. It looked as if we had gone back in time 20 or 30 years. Had I been alone with my dad in that room, I would have thought that my eyes were playing tricks on me - that I imagined what I saw. Because my mother, my brother and I all saw the beautiful change in my father’s appearance, I know that it really happened. It was somehow comforting to see him in this way. He truly looked like he was at peace. (On a side note, I have seen other family members right before they died, but nobody’s face transformed like my dad's did!)

My mother was 91. She had been unresponsive for some weeks and on Tuesday of the week she died on Friday, she had a change. Her coma, if that’s what it was, deepened. Through those days we did what should be done for a person who was dying. We washed her body and we talked about her and about us while we waited. Friday morning of that week came and she dropped farther into unconsciousness. Hospice came and we all waited. She was so thin that we could see her veins in her arms and we watched her pulse as it slowed and slowed until she was very close to her death. The nurse stayed back and let us be with our mother as she died. And she did die. I was holding her hand when she died and it was an immediate vice grip tight and strong hold. I pulled my hand away from hers as quickly as I could. Then I looked at her naked body and there was a glistening of her skin - a shimmering effect. I don’t know how long because everybody got very busy, very active in documenting her death. It had to be okay for her to be dead. I forgot about it and things proceeded with the end of her life. I believe I have read about this and that there is a name for it. I want to say it’s in the bible and it may be but I can’t tell you where. I think that’s what happened - a physiological event happened and I saw it. Maybe so when this question came up I could answer it for you.

When my Grandma was in the hospital dying of cancer some strange stuff happened in that room. First off, she kept talking about a “being” that was standing at the foot of her bed. She couldn't tell if it was a man or a woman but she kept asking who they were. There was nobody there and i kept trying to reassure her of that but she was adament that someone was standing guard at the foot of her bed. Then, for about an hour my Grandmother started speaking in her native language which she had all but forgotten as an adult, but was speaking fluently, as if she were a child again. About an hour before she died, she looked over at the empty hospital bed next to hers, let out a gasp and started talking to my dead grandpa (her husband). She was crying and telling him how much she’d missed him and had what seemed like a conversation with him. She went quiet for a while and finally passed, and at that moment I swear I felt her “leave”. It wasn't anything bold or over the top, but it was so tangible. That “thing” that made her *her* had left. That whole last day in her hospital room had an almost eerie, other worldly feel to it that I know a lot of people will brush off as a “dying brain” etc, but I felt something else in the room that day, something deeper than that that I'll never forget.

When my cat Rogue was euthanized the vet pushed the final drug before I was ready. After unexpectedly hearing her say “I’m sorry, but her heart has stopped beating now” I lost my grip on reality. Biologist or not–I simply could not understand what had happened, how my beloved could just be gone. The vet had wisely scurried away. I begged my mother to explain to me why Rogue wasn’t moving, why she was limp. I scooped her up in my arms and she was like a toy. She looked the same, but all the tension had gone from her muscles. After a few minutes, the pink had gone from her nose and her precious toe beans and the inside of her ears had turned white. They hadn’t taken the delicate pearl that they did when she was sleeping or snuggling with me, but rather a blank, bone color.  It was nearing the end of the work day and my mother didn’t want to inconvenience the vet. She tried to take Rogue’s body from me; I’d never been so angry at anyone before or since. I clung to her tighter and refused to give her up. Eventually, I had stopped crying for long enough for my nose to clear. I buried my face in her luscious fur, wanting to smell her intoxicating catty scent one more time. But it was gone. She smelled… wrong. Not like death, not bad, but just wrong. Like nothing. Her smell was gone. She was gone and I could understand that.

My BIL, my husband and I were with my MIL as she died. We had left hospice, exhausted. The nurse had told us her passing would be soon, but to go home, and get some respite. At 11 PM, we were called back to the ward. They were sure she would die that night. The previous Friday, Mom had asked for her good friend to come and talk to her. Fred was a wonderful human being who had been amazing help to my amazing mother in law. He had even helped her find her long lost sister, who she had been searching for, for 57 yrs! (He found the sister in one day) Fred had been a minister. Although we don’t know the discussions, I presume that it was a last ‘confession’. Mom didn’t speak again after that. On the night of her death, we listened as her breathing became more and more shallow. We gather close, and held her hand so she wouldn’t be frightened in that dimly lit room. We spoke to her, to give whatever love and comfort we could share. It was surprising how gently she died. She didn’t fight for breath. We did hear the death rattle. We wondered when the last breath would be. The room had muted lighting, and perhaps we wouldn’t be able to know. However, that’s not what happened. Somehow, after the last breath, Mom looked different. I don’t know how to describe it. It truly was an immediate alteration. As soon as I saw that change, I looked up into the corners of the room. Some people have reported some sort of essence upon death, that what was that person leaves the body, and hovers above the scene. I didn’t observe this. However, when I thought back on it, I believe her essence left her body after her visit with her dear friend. She was at peace. She was no longer fearful. She was relaxed and able to let go. I miss you, Mom. You were a gem, precious, strong and brilliant in all your facets.

Yes, something awesome yet startling in the moment. My family is from a small island off Italy but I was raised elsewhere. My great-grandmother was an amazingly independent immigrant, divorce, and entrepreneur who lived a beautiful, and full life despite extreme adversity after the war. I used to go to her home in Australia and she would cook for me, fix all my clothes, and give me things from Italy. One day I knew was special. She gave me a gold rosary from our town in Italy that she had been saving. She gave one to all the women: me, my sister, my grandmother, and even one for my mother who had since divorced my dad. She was thoughtful to her core in that way. I knew when she was dying and it happened quietly. I was notified with a phone call as I was living in the US. I remembered the rosary and started carrying it everywhere I go. Sometime later the rosary was in it’s little box in the middle of my desk. I mean dead set middle, on top of some books. Not on the edge. Not on a slope. In the middle. I was in my room in a very, very dark time in moment I won’t get into here. I heard a noise behind me, so I turned around quickly, terrified. The rosary had popped out of it’s box and was laid perfectly across the floor of my room like it had been placed. I broke down. I knew immediately I wasn’t alone and how to be strong. About a year later, that rosary was stolen from my bag in Barcelona and I absolutely lost my mind when I realized. This year for my graduation, my sister handed me her rosary from my great grandmother across the table as my gift. I cried and told her it was the nicest gift she could have given me.

Not immediately but before my mother passed away in 2010 she told me she would try to send me a sign from the other side when she died. Years passed and nothing happened. One night I was with some friends and my friend Kevin who had a mother who passed away said he woke up one night to the strong scent of her perfume in his room. I told him about my mom’s promise and that I envied him. Later that same night I was driving home on a normally busy street that was deserted at that hour. There were street lights so it was well lit. Suddenly out of the sky, very close in front of me came this enormous shooting star. It was extremely bright and huge and it seemed to be right over the street not that far up from the street lights. I was in shock and I even braked - it felt like the star was going to go down right in front of my car. I had never seen a shooting stat so close even though it was probably farther away then I thought. Then it just disappeared into the darkness on the other side of the street. I felt as if Mon had finally sent me a sign although I guess it could have been a coincidence.

Once after the girl I loved most in my life passed away in a car accident, while I was on a road trip in California on the other side of the country, I saw some unusual things. This was before I knew she had passed away I began to think about her a lot more, thoughts and memories of her filled my mind completely. Also I was on a run in California through some suburbs and took the same way out as I did returning on the run back. On one section of sidewalk on an overpass, I ran through a clear sidewalk, running through the middle due to no one else being around. Then while returning on the run back across the same patch of sidewalk on the overpass not more than 20 minutes later, there was this little dead bird laying peacefully in the middle of my path. I stopped and looked at it and felt emotionally moved by the sight. It was a small little bird petite and fragile looking just like my recently passed friend. I took a few pictures of it with my iPhone to not forget it and cause I felt like I should, then continued my run. It wasn't until a week or two later that I found out the tragic news and that bird did eventually end up crossing my mind a few times more. Looking back, I slightly felt the same feeling of sorrow suddenly seeing that bird as I did hearing and trying to accept the news of Jolie's death, just on very different scales.

I lost both my grandmother and my uncle in the same week two years ago. There were many noticeable changes to my life and the lives of my family members, but one incident stands out to me. It was a few days after my grandmother’s death. I estimate that it was around two or three in the morning, and I was attempting to sleep. I’m not sure what initiated this idea, but I suddenly thought that someone had come into my room. Whether I had heard my door creaking slightly or detected soft footsteps, I’m not sure. There was no obvious sign that someone had entered my room, but I felt it, so much so that I asked, into the darkness, if my mom was standing there. Something I was feeling in that moment told me that my grandmother had come into the room. I have no rational explanation for this feeling, but I know that I felt her presence there. The rational side of my brain doesn’t believe in the paranormal or any form of life after death. But, in that moment, I definitely thought that she had come from beyond death to visit me. I do believe that there are things about this world that we cannot understand. We are surrounded by unexplained phenomena, and I’m not sure when, if ever, we will discover satisfactory explanations for them. And that is why, even though I don’t truly believe that my grandmother’s spirit or soul lingered after she died, I still thought that she had come to see me on that night.

My aunt had a missed diagnosis of lung cancer that metastasized to her spine. In her final months she came home to live with her sister, my mother, and I was part of the team helping to care for her. We all are really good cooks in my family, so one thing we would talk about was food and different recipes. She and I had started to create a summer dessert recipe shortly before she died, and unfortunately, never got the chance to finish it before she passed after a quick down-turn in her health. I got the call at about 6 in the morning on December 7th that she had finally passed in her sleep. All that morning I could feel a restlessness in my house and the idea for the dessert would NOT get out of my head. Finally I sat down and just wrote everything out that was racing around in my head. Shortly after I finished it seemed like there was a sigh of relief and love filling the room which slowly faded over a few hours. Once more that night I sensed my dear aunt checking in on me and I knew she was at peace and loved us. All she wanted was to give me that final piece of her that we had been working on. I made that dessert for her memorial service last month. My mom has her own account of her sister checking in a couple of times that same day, but neither of us has sensed her since. We know she is resting now.

My mother died suddenly after a serious fall that broke ribs and punctured her lung. At the hospital she bled out and was gone within a few hours. I live about 8 hours away and drove up the next day. My sisters and I tried to sort out her possessions, each taking things that were valuable to each of us. My daughter flew up the day before her funeral and picked out a few things. We packed these in my car since we were leaving the next day. One item she had picked out was a musical jewelry box that belonged to my mother. Even though were were driving all around the next day the music box was silent until just when we drove up and parked at the church for the service. My daughter, my son in law and I were all astonished when right after we parked the car, suddenly the music box piped up and played a tune. We all looked at each other and we all agreed it was a message. I know it was my mother. We attended the service and the reception and then started the long trek home. The music box remained silent in the car the entire way. It has been a few years now and the music box has never played by itself again, only when it is wound. It played by itself only that one time as we pulled up to the church for her funeral.

I have come across lots of questions to answer but i wasn't sure if i was doing justice enough to answer them. But this question deserves answering because it's really heartbreaking to even notice the change. You see, when the ’one’ is alive, you would agree that out of 100%, 20–40% of your problems would have been solved by your friends, 50% by your siblings, relatives or known people & 100% by your parents. But beyond problems is the love we get from them in various forms yet once they depart (some of you also must have thoughts like this) we start remembering them with what they could have done for us if s(he) was alive. For eg: If you were here you would have helped me find my way.If she was here she would have done things for me.If he was here I wouldn't have to go through all this mess.I wish she was here, i am so alone without her.If mom was here she would have cooked my favourite dish.When father was alive i didnt need to worry about my future.The list could go on and on and on. I haven't yet came across anyone who would just want that person back in life not for what they could have done for them. Something like, “love me…just me for who i am not because what i can do for you.” Every single one remembered the dead ones for what they could have done for them. Not to mention about the greedy ones. It's not that they don't love them. They must have loved them 99% but its after death we are talking about. The change. I guess this is one of the many harsh reality of life. My father once said “if it wasn't for the fire burning in our stomach, we would not care for others” we give them attention because we need them. We all need each other. Lastly, my answer may or may not be of your like but still thank you for reading. You have my respect.

I was present when my father passed away three weeks ago. July 6th 2017. I was on the night shift with my mom, one of my brother and one of my sisters-in-law. Essentially nothing happened. My brother was just whispering :”It’s OK dad, you can let go.” Then we just noticed the sudden absence of sound. My mom was 10 feet away. We told her:”Mom, it’over.” We called the nurse. She checked. Called another nurse to make sure. No breathing on the mirror, no movement of the diaphragm. We were happy that its suffering from intestinal cancer was over. What two of my brothers, my sister-in-law and I can’t stand is what happened the night before when he was still strong enough to suffer. Asking “Pourquoi moi? “Why me?”. Waving his arms in the air to lessen the suffering from having no longer enough flesh to support himself. Asking for water though he couldn’t drink anymore. My sis-in-law soaking his lips with a swab and each time being told :”Merci, merci.” “Thanks, thanks.” Why wasn’t I allowed to end his suffering? I wish no ethicist or pseudo-religious nitwit ever talk to me about the sanctity of human life and explain why I was forced to treat my personal hero worse than a dog. The dying was the easiest part. The nightmares are the worst.

My mother’s father had broken up her relationship with Ray when they were 18. They wanted to marry and move to California from New York. Grandpa told her she must stay and contribute money to the family so her younger sister, Vera, could go to nursing school. Mother, Ginny, was unhappy for the rest of her life. They both had married, she unhappily. Ray came across the country to see her every few years. Fast forward now to 1991 when she died just short of her 78th birthday. My sister and I were sitting at the table in moms house when someone knocks on the door. I answer it to see Ray standing there! He said that two days earlier, he knew something was wrong and he had to come here. He told his wife and hopped a plane from San Francisco to Fort Myers, Florida! How did Ray know? We hadn't called him. Nothing was in the paper. Yet Ray knew! Note: To understand how this happened immediately, as your question asks, please remember Ray showed up at the door in less than 24 hrs after mom’s death. Her mental communication with him had to be immediately upon her dying, He came across the county.

Yes and it has changed the face of my fate 100% I remember a morning when I was 12, maybe in early spring or late winter, my mom and I sat eating breakfast just the two of us at Roy Rogers. She was reading the paper and found an article about three sisters, one of which was dying, so they made a “sign” for her to send to the other two sisters to show she was at peace after she died. It was a red balloon I believe, or maybe yellow, regardless the day after she passed and the home came to get her body she had magically been changed into a sweater with a red balloon. So at breakfast my mom and I decide to make a sign, a ladybug. Fast forward a few months, my best friend, my dad died suddenly of a stroke, three days before I turn 13. The day of his funeral I am in my moms bathroom getting dressed, rooting through one of the drawers to find a hairbrush and there it is, a ladybug keychain I had never seen before. Since that day the ladybug sign comes to me often, even still almost eight years later. I know it's him, even though he wasn't present when my mom and I declared the ladybug as our sign. I turn 21 next week and just today I was weeding right after a heavy rain, as I went to stand up, one little ladybug was on my shoulder.

I have, yes. Although, maybe not in the way you’re expecting. My sister suddenly died around 5am in our home. That same day, in the tree in our front yard, was a mourning dove. We only had one tiny, pathetic tree in our yard. There were much fuller, healthier trees all around us in our neighbors yards. But, this bird chose our tree. And that wasn’t all. We later noticed she had a nest and an egg. I had never seen a mourning dove in person. I recognized the strangeness of the kind of bird that we had in our yard. I decided to google the symbolism. What Are Mourning Doves?By virtue of their melancholy call, mourning doves have been fittingly named. Their distinctive “wooo-oo-oo-oo" sounds may evoke a feeling of grief over the loss of a dearly beloved. But far from representing death, the symbolism of mourning doves gives us optimism with its spirituality. Beyond their sorrowful song is a message of life, hope, renewal and peace. Not long after her passing, we noticed the dove was gone. We also assumed the baby had hatched because the egg was also nowhere to be seen. We left the nest for a while then we carefully removed it from the tree and displayed it in a glass dome. We take symbolism seriously. We firmly believe the dove was sent to us for a reason during that difficult time.

In my experience with my mom, the ‘before’ someone passes can be so much deeper and interesting than the after. My mom passed 5 years ago from cancer. We had been waiting for her departure for a while, but it still catches you by surprise. I vividly remember how incredulous I was of the old folks tales that the loved ones come to pick up their descendants once its their turn to leave. During her last week we had her old friends and closest relatives come and visit her to say goodbye (looking back i wish i had invested that time with just direct family, but i guess she belonged to her history). I remember her cousin patricia was looking at her with the saddest look in her face, just staring while tears rolled down her cheeks. My mom was just too interested in who was behind her. She kept on asking my aunt who were those tall men that were behind her cousin, she described them as white, blue-eyed with blond curly hair and a light surrounding them. Later that day she kept on asking about the extra people in the room, and talking to her dad and aunt. The after is so much less interesting. After she left i felt completely empty and hopeless. I felt completely alone in her room; it sort of felt like someone left me talking mid-sentence. I could see her body, she was just not there. I just hope she’ll come and pick me up when it’s my time, I’ll be so happy to see her again.

I was once staring abstractedly off into space while filling up my van. The road in front of the gas station was a 4 lane highway with an intersection not too far to my left. I heard the crotch rocket, which apparently had been stopped by a red light on the highway, take off and come my way. It was a Friday afternoon and I knew someone was happy to be getting off work and beat the commuter traffic. I didn’t really process the old lady pulling out of the gas station but saw the motorcycle slam into the side of her car, like an explosion: the front end of the bike went flying through the air, the back end folded up like an accordion. The car was knocked across the road into a ditch. I immediately started running toward the crumpled heap in the road and noted the guy was dressed well: leathers all over, nice full protection helmet. I knew better than to move him but I took off his leather gloves and held his hand while I told him to hang on. I noticed all his fingers were outlined in blue. He took a deep breath and died. A few seconds later I felt this incredible whooshing sensation rushing past me upward into the sky. I’ll never forget that. Later I read the obituary. He was 22, just married.

I would not say immediately, but I did notice something I could not explain within a relatively short time of a loved one passing. About a month after my mom passed away, I was getting ready to take a shower. I gathered some of my toiletries together to take with me in the bathroom, but I got distracted by an article I was reading on my computer. After I was done reading, I walked into the bathroom, closed the door behind me, and got into the shower. I realized then that I had forgotten my shampoo and conditioner bottles on my dresser in my bedroom. Reluctantly, I stepped out of the shower to go back and get it, but when I looked to my right on the countertop in the bathroom, both bottles were there. I stood there in shock for what seemed an eternity. I started to question my sanity, did I think I forgot them but I had taken them with me all along, why would I leave it there of all places, I badgered myself. I realized that I was not losing my mind. I felt a warm feeling envelop me, like someone was watching out for me. I still feel that way. There is some things in life we can’t explain because it is just too great to perceive beyond the reality our minds create.

I have only witnessed a person’s death once. My 93-year-old mother had been in hospice care, lingering near death (dying of heart failure) for a week. She had stopped eating or drinking, and was being given “comfort” medications. According to her own “living will” she did not want intubation or CPR or tube feeding or any invasive measures to prolong her life. She was not in physical pain. My brother, my lady, and myself were the only ones in the room. My brother was the only one who noticed anything — he said, “I think she’s dead”. He had been watching her more closely than us. She had stopped breathing. She was completely still. We called in the hospice nurse, and she confirmed the lack of heartbeat or respiration. None of us witnessed anything supernatural or mystical. To me, my mother (her “soul or self”) had gone away to another place. The body in the bed was a lifeless husk.

My dad was dying, after a stroke he could only a couple hours without respiration. They brought him home from the hospital. After 10 weeks ICU he was home. The ambulance staff took him on his stretcher trough the garden, trough his workshop, to his car, a long the pond and his fish. It was farewell for him and very touching. The next day he died, he was slightly sedated so he would not have the feeling he chokes and panic. He slept, like a child on his side with his knees pulled up.The moment he died we were all there, his wife for 60 years, five sons, two daugters, son and daughters in law and his ten grandchildren. I experienced before when pets died that I felt them leaving, I felt their energy leave. I never knew what to think of that and I realy realy did not expect to feel anything like that at this moment.But I did, I felt his energy. bundle and leave, it was green and white in a geometric like pattern and it went trough my belly and pelvis and left…I was glad, I knew it was ok.

Some of my observations are: 1. The eyeballs of many people are observed as if the person was trying to see something above his head. This can be explained well in terms of spirit. The spirit leaves a body from bottom up, starting from the toes and ending up at head. Thus the eyes try to see the leaving spirit. 2. Another observation is some people look as if they were sleeping unless it's told that they are no more. And some seem as if they are smiling (like my dear father who went away 2 years ago). And some are seen as if they were feeling too much pain just before death. 3. And this last one. While carrying the body of the deceased to the funeral ground, I have myself observed that some people become extra heavier than they actually were before death. Contrary to this, some bodies are felt too light than expected as per their build.  I can only say that there are many things which are beyond our understanding and even science is unable to explain them.

I have witnessed two deaths/funerals closely. No. 1: Grandmother She is lying on the bed. My mother is sitting beside her, massaging her head, my uncle massaging her feet. I am also sitting on the bed. I listen to her breathing slow down, her eyes blinking furiously for 20 seconds then slowing down and finally closing 10 seconds later. People start crying, hugging each other, making phone calls.. No. 2: Grandfather The dead body of my grandfather arrives at our place where the proceedings of his funeral are supposed to be carried out. Every fifteen minutes, a new family arrives at our house. People, as usual, are crying and hugging each other. What I noticed: Despite all the crying and wailing that is taking place, I feel peace in the air. It feels as if a soul has finally freed itself from these worldly confines and is now happily dancing in the air. It feels like we are all stuck in a prison. We are being freed one by one. I feel happy for the prisoners that are leaving, while I wait not so patiently for my turn.

My 12 year old son, Gabriel Michael Jacobs, collapsed playing a game of basketball with his 3 brothers and dad right in our back yard. It was like he just quickly looked up and then laid down. He didn't fall hard and there was no bleeding. I noticed lots of things that are worth mentioning, but I will share this: On the exact same day and the exact same time three weeks after my son passed away, his 2 older brothers played their first game of basketball in Gabe's honor…and they looked up and saw a smiling face rainbow right in our yard. The most amazing sign from Gabriel that he is happy in Heaven. We call it Gabriel smiling from Heaven. We started HOME in his honor!

No explanations for these experiences  but open to suggestions: My husband is away in Quito, has heart problems but is out of the hospital and appears to be better.  I see him in my dream at the foot of my bed in Gainesville, very pale, “what a surprise!” Doesn’t say a word, stares at me, turns around and leaves through a door. Shortly after I receive a call with news of his sudden death.Again in Gainesville, worn out after heavy work, I doze off in my living room.  Someone is standing next to my sofa, I clearly recognize my nephew who has died a year earlier.  Again, very pale, he is smiling and beckoning  someone behind me who does not want to be seen.  Next morning I learn my very close and dear  niece has committed suicide.At home, waiting for two students who need my help.  Doorbell rings, it is one of my students, “And where is your friend?”, “Coming on her own,” she says.  We close the door and both hear a voice jokingly asking “and I cannot come in?” Open the door and there is no one there. Next morning my sister is dead.These personal experiences (and several more) lead me believe there is something there unknown to us.

Having been a Registered Nurse for forty three years I can honestly say I have witnessed many many deaths. Some had family with them and in other cases they were alone. If they were alone I spent as much time with them as I could and talked to them. I can tell you that when death has come and the last breath or two have left, I swear, something lifts up from the body and rises. What I saw was this “something” basically hovering over the body about the size of the body. The closest thing I can think of to describe it is it was something like very dense air. You can see heat waves rise from a highway on a hot day. I could see what I presumed to be the essence of the body or soul leaving. The body after the essence left was definitely different. It was a shell, a hull left behind. It never scared me to witness this. I counted it a privilege to be there and witness their passing.

About three weeks ago my brother died. He had been Cheyne-Stokes breathing for two days and his family had gathered around on the evening of the second day as they were progressively increasing his morphine injections. (Cheyne–Stokes respiration is characterized by a repeating pattern of progressively deeper and faster breathing, followed by a temporary stop in breathing of up to 1 minute.) A number of times we thought he was dead, but he was tough and survived till morning. The next day the family took it in turns to be with him. At 8 PM my partner Glenda and I noticed a sudden change; his breathing became regular, fast and shallow. This continued for a few minutes and then he took a huge gasp of air and stopped and lay still. His pulse was barely discernable. After about 30 seconds his face became dark purple with masses of blotches the size of match heads. About a minute later the colour drained fom his face and he looked like a translucent figure carved from beeswax. I don’t know the exact point of death.

I was alone with my mother when she died, and there was nothing heartwarming or transcendent happened.  She simply stopped breathing and her pulse stopped. I had already called the EMT’s and they came in and did their best, but she was dead. Nothing was going to bring her back, and for me, in a bit of shock as it was unexpected, the end of life was so profound that what she had been simply wasn’t anymore.  It’s a very final ending.

If I had been close to a person, or at least known of them, I know that sometimes souls take their time to depart. Usually about a week to say goodbye to those that were close to them. Sometimes, just before someone close dies, I have the feeling that something (a death) will occur and I will start to worry who it will be. But for my own experience: My Great Aunt and paternal Grandma both visited me in dreams. The first, I was standing in the doorway of my Great Aunt’s house, and she was on the steps. She game me a hug through the doorway, and the whole dream disappeared in a flash of sunlight. My Grandma visited our apartment, pressed a keyring with two keys into my hand and clamped my fingers down hard on it. She wished me a long and happy marriage like she had (she and her husband died well into their 80s). My paternal Grandpa visited me in the funeral home. Just started chatting. A then-boyfriend’s mother passed and she came by my apartment to say goodbye. Both were equally surprised that I could “commune with the dead”, but were happy about it.

No. I saw my mother die five years ago. She stopped breathing. And that was it. She had cancer, & was too frail for anything more than palliative care, so that was what she got, at home because that’s where she wanted to be. One night it became obvious that she didn’t have long, so my stepfather called me & my sister. We got there while she was still conscious (only just, in my case: all I got from her was a smile & a squeeze of my hand), so we could say goodbye. Then we waited, taking turns to sleep. She was still alive by morning, & I was sitting by her. Her breathing had got more laboured through the night, & then there was a catch - a stop & start. Then a bigger one. I called my stepfather, & then her breathing stopped & didn’t restart. Her face seemed to sag. That’s it. Nothing else. We noted the time, & called her GP. Duty doctor arrived within half an hour to certify her death.

My uncle was dying a few years ago. Wet lived in different states. He was a great man. He was a police officer, and was my guide as l went through life. I was sitting at the bedside of a patient, waiting for them to pass along with their family. The family said that she wasn't necessarily afraid to die. She was afraid of taking the journey alone. I had gotten word before my shift that my uncle was actively dying. I was standing with my back to a wall and felt a tap on the back of my right shoulder. You know like someone was saying here I am. Then my patient passed. I always step ity of the room to give the family alone time at that point. I was thinking how gay it was that my uncle came do this lady wouldn't be done. My aunt called too say that my uncle had just passed. I simply said, “I know. He came and got my patient.” Then I I hung up, provided final cares for my patient, and prepared to go to Austin for my uncle's funeral.

“That darn red bird wakes me up every morning, Ma.” That was my brother complaining to my mom about how a red little bird would peck at his window and wake him up every single morning. The bird never missed a day of pestering my brother. “I am going to catch that bird and get him back.” A few days later my brother passed away. He was twenty years old. (We live in Texas and Cardinals are not too common here.) I have never cried like the day I cried on the day of the viewing. After the viewing when we were leaving, we heard a bird chirping. It was a cardinal, standing on a tree, chirping, watching us, soothing us. It was my brother embracing us, telling us everything was going to be ok and that he was fine. Cardinals are symbolism of a loved one who has passed, they are believed to also be spiritual messengers. After my brother passed we would sometimes see the Cardinal by my brothers window, or in our backyard. It has been almost 4 years and till this day we still randomly see our Cardinal friend especially in times of need like the holidays.

I saw my grandmother dying 3 years ago. I was seeing a dead body for the first time in my life. We needed to do all customs before 12. As a piece of custom we needed to bathe her before we could take her to the burial ground. My mom and close relatives were doing this custom. What i saw was, as soon as water touched her body, the skin swollen up and there were goosebumps all over her body. I was so stunned. It is safe to say that she is as yet alive? Why ain't she talking kinda thoughts circled me. Everybody was stunned. I couldn't rest by any means. I continued asking my mother but she ignored. Later I googled and attempted to comprehend the explanation for it. There is some logical reason (skin cells take time to become lifeless) It was horrific.

This didn’t instantly happen after my mother died, but while my mother was being buried. It was late January, and the weather was cool — around 5ºC/~40ºF. We had flowers around the gravesite. As the minister was saying, “In my father’s house are many mansions. If it were not so, I would have told you. I go to prepare a place for you”, I heard a LOUD buzzing of what appeared to be a single bee or bumblebee around the flowers. My mother used to be a beekeeper. My first thought was, what is a honeycomb if not a house of many mansions. I think that Mom was telling me that she was okay, and, yes, she was in a house of many mansions. When my partner and I married, about a year and a half later, I made a point of using rolled honeycomb candles at the wedding. It was my way of including Mom in the ceremony. Since then I believe that the way God communicates with us is by putting ‘bees in our bonnet’ — ideas in our head.

My husband died nearly five years ago. He died of bile duct cancer, only 12 days after diagnosis. He died very peacefully, and I and our girls were there. He stopped breathing, and there was a deep, deep silence but it still felt as though he were still IN his body. He was there, and I could feel him. Then, about 25 minutes later, the oddest thing happened. it was as though someone had opened a door in a tightly closed room, and then closed it suddenly. The air did this whoomp whoomp thing……and he was GONE. 0ne second he was still there and then he was absolutely and irrevocably gone. My youngest daughter gasped, and looked right at me and asked "did you FEEL that?" And I nodded. She said quite simply " somewhere, a baby just received a great soul". I think she was right.

My Mother was married before my Father to a man that was killed in a gas station robbery. The murder was not solved for over 23 years. It was miraculously solved several months after my Mother died. One of the suspects was arrested for unrelated drug charges. The guy had left a bag of chips on the counter during the robbery and murder with his prints. His finger print tied him to the crime and when the police questioned him he confessed to the murder. Thomson men charged in 23-year-old slaying Not saying she solved it from the grave, but the case was considered a cold case that was no longer being investigated. It was then solved (open and shut) in just a few months of her death.

My mother went into the arms of Jesus on Saturday, March 4, 2017. The hospice doctor gave her only hours to live on Thursday, but she was waiting for me and my youngest brother and was still conscious when we arrived Saturday afternoon. Soon she lapsed into unconsciousness, and that evening my cousin, a nurse, told her it was ok to go. She immediately heaved a sigh and left us. At that moment the song “I Can Only Imagine,” which is about heaven, was playing on the TV right near her bed. It was a sweet reminder to me and my brothers that Mom is with the Lord in glory now. I rejoice that she is no longer in pain and that we were able to say goodby.

No. But I’ve witnessed something just before my father died.  He had cancer. At the time of his death me and my sister were standing on each side of his bed at the hospital. There wasn’t anyone else. I was looking at him and he was looking at my sister, with the saddest eyes I’ve ever seen. My sister was also looking and they had eye contact.  Then I saw a change in his eyes. His look changed. It wasn’t fear. It was amazement and then to something that I can only describe as acceptance. And then I saw his eyes close and his head just drop on one side.  My sister later said that for the last few moments he was looking right next to her.

My dad passed away 5 weeks ago. He was in excruciating pain. He had prostate cancer that mestasized to his bones and it was very painful. My dad fought hard and proud before he totally succumbed to this bitch disease. I could not be next to him when he left this world but based on my mom’s story there were two things that overtook the moments after his death. There was an extraordinary numb sad emptiness that felt like the whole universe just stopped that felt like forever.There was an extraordinary peace. Like when you sit next to a quiet lake in a summer evening.RIP Dad, and sorry I could not be there with you on your final trip…

Years ago I was in a patient’s room as she was dying. She was in a lot of pain from cancer and her stomach was very distended. She asked me why it hurt so much and I told her it would be alright and the medicine would work very soon. A few minutes later as I was holding her hand she asked” Why are they all around me”? I asked her who she was talking about. She lifted her frail little hand and said”Them”. “They are all around me” as she followed them with her eyes. She was Catholic so I told her that maybe they are angels or some special people who love her. She passed away the next day. I loved that lady she was so sweet and kind and she passed peacefully.

I was present when my mum died. She was in hospital, we had been watching her heartbeat line sink below critical for a couple of days. The minute she died the body was still. This is a stillness that is never present in a live being. Unnervingly still. No breathing, no motion, nothing. It was very clear that this body was no longer my mother, it was just a dead body. The nurses asked us to leave and then cleaned up and let us back in. By the time we went back in - 30 minutes later-ish - the blood had started settling. So it was pooling inside her body at the bottom - making the skin closest to the bed sort of purple. No pumping heart, no method of keeping the blood circulating. I didn't know that happened.

Apparently, shortly after a person dies, they emit a gaseous “death plume” with a specific molecular signature. The US Army has exploited this “death plume” by developing a remote Raman detection device for remotely detecting this “death plume” so as to determine whether a recently injured soldier is alive or dead. One merely shines an infra-red laser beam toward the downed soldier and then measure and characterize the scatter light. This is useful because, if the dead soldier is in a zone of active enemy fire, the Army doesn’t need to put a rescuer’s life at risk by needlessly retrieving the body while the enemy fire persists. See: US Pat. App. No. 2015/0323464.

I really find it very weird and funny how people act when someone they know is gone .They might say different things depending upon who they are Those having tender heart —These people for a moment start caring about dead people .In there whole life they might have not talked to them .Not smiled at them for once .but, when they are gone ,they are going to cry for them One who thinks bad about the dead —He usually tells that “kaisa v tha,dil ka accha aaadmi tha..kabhi kuch bura nhi kiya” Significant ones —They won't say anything they will just sob ,cry and cry more Stupid ones—They don't give a shit Mature ones—They might not cry ,they will keep it low.Only there heart knows what they feel .

I was a hospice social worker in a large medical center and one of our patients was a brother in a religious order. He was dying and the head of his community and other brothers came to say good bye. He died after a little while and while my team and I were consoling them, they asked if we would pray with them. This was about 5 minutes after he passed, and we stood in a circle next to the man’s bed. I don’t remember the prayer but I do remember a blue light filled the room and all of us felt a sense of peace. It was an awesome experience and while I don’t want to die any time soon, I’m not afraid of it.

I was at that time 12 years on a bed,was in a hospital in ER. I was diagnosed with malaria and getting my vitals checked. At the same time a cardiac patient came right in and all i could hear was that the person in description, has lost his heart beat. I wad in shock like what would you expect from a 12yo. An hour or so later, he passed away. But the thing unusual was the wind. I remember it being summers and the room was cooled with stable air conditioners that are safe for small infants, like you can experience any strong wind inside. Coincidently a breeze blew right at the foot of my bed followed by a gush of sand-storm. It was pretty unusual for me.

Yes.  And this somehow makes me feel sad and happy at the same time. It's somehow poignant and heartbreaking. After you die, people stop addressing you by your name. 'The body has been sent for postmortem.’ 'The body will arrive by this afternoon.’ 'The body was discovered by the local fishermen.’ You stop being a person. You lose every title, accomplishments and honours that once meant everything to you. All that is left is a dead pile of flesh and bones that somehow is you, but not good enough to be considered as the real you. Doesn't matter who you were before, after death, you lose your identity, you become one with everything and everyone that existed before you. You become a (no)body.

I haven’t witnessed someone’s passing, but I'll never forget the description my grandmother gave to me when describing the death of her first husband. I never knew my grandpa, but from the stories I've been told from other people, he suffered with rheumatoid arthritis for most of his adult life and was always in physical pain. My grandmother told me that as soon as he took his last breath a big smile came over his face. She knew at that moment he was finally free of all of his pain.

One of my employees has been an E.M.T. for 20 years and during that time he noticed; Gun casings.Bag of money.blood… and more blood…Grey matter.The smell of shit.Sense of loss, sometimes sense of joy.Bad decisions.Poorly tied noose.Open alcohol containers.Unbuckled seat belts.Frozen head to the front of a train (long story).The list goes on and on…I assume you mean something supernatural. To that, his answer is NO.

I’ve had people die in my arms, literally. What amazes me isn't something supernatural, but how some people worry about possessions even at the end. I had a woman concerned about a valuable end table while I moved her to a stretcher. She coded 5 minutes later. This doesn't answer your question, but it came to mind. Life is precious, make sure to live it.

Witnessed this first hand Before death: He is not a good person, he always lies, doesn't care about family, thinks only he is right all others are wrong, very arrogant, feels as if he is the boss of everyone. After death: SAME PEOPLE He was not that bad, he once helped me, he gave me a very good watch, he was always smiling, sometimes he used to get angry but only for family's benefit. Why can't we see good things before death?

When my grandmother breathed her last breath, I was the one holding her hand. Right after that, I felt something move from her into me. I know it sounds crazy, and I’ve never believed in anything like this happening, but I definitely felt it.

The last weekend of my Father’s life, I was sitting in his hospital room when he, while sound asleep, began actively began speaking Italian. I knew my Dad remembered very little Italian from his youth. When he woke up, I asked him with whom he had been speaking. He said, “My Mother” (who never learned to speak English). He died two days later. I believe his Mother was there to assist him in passing through to his new life.

I witnessed my great-grandmother’s death. She was my paternal grandfather’s aunt. She died of old age. This is a small home in a small village in a country side. My aunt was trying to get her to drink some water but she wasn’t drinking it. She was wheezing. And then it was over. I remember standing there staring at her gaping mouth and soulless eyes, transfixed, as my aunt covered her up with tears in her eyes. My 60+ year old grandpa carried her outside the room. That’s when she peed. I guess her bladder released the fluid now that her muscles relaxed. It was such a strange thing. In her life, all of her 90 years, she had been a strict, principled woman who had remained unmarried and raised my motherless grandfathers. Death is the most humbling truth of life.

I was 19 weeks pregnant and my waters had broken almost a week before. I was told there was no hope. The afternoon before I went into hospital, the clock in my living room stopped ticking. A couple hours later I was at hospital waiting to deliver my stillborn baby boy. I’m convinced my son passed away when the clock stopped. I even turned it around because I was sure this is what it meant.

I like to go outside and observe nature. That usually tells me something when my grandfather died I saw this twinkling star that kept twinkling it’s light on me. To me that’s a sign he was looking over me. Then when my friend passed away I looked outside and I saw a white dove. This means the bringing of peace and heaven gaining an angel. A couple of days after I kept seeing white feathers when I took out the trash. Their spirit always remains alive remember that.

They become very still and you notice their skin stillness and lack of absolute motion it unnerving. No movement of their stomachs or chest. Their faces go limp, they relax their jaws. The emotional feeling is the worst, there is nothing there, the finality of it, is so horrifying. You can feel their minds, their brain, it’s like they’ve been erased. It’s a lump of tissue ,who resembles someone you’ve loved. I’ve never seen ghosts, shapes, or anything, it’s just quiet and silence.

If you mean something attributable to the death, I’ve seen a lot of people die, but I’ve never seen any effects (other than sadness and that sort of thing). Some non-repeatable experiments have shown (or the claimants have claimed that they showed) a slight loss of weight at the moment of death, “proving” the existence of a “soul” that was leaving the body at death - but that’s all they were, non-repeatable claims. (The body can lose weight at the moment of death - through purely physical means. Sphincter muscles can spasm or relax at death.)

I was camping with a friend at Big Sur in California. I was grumpy out of sorts, unsettled and unhappy and finally she got fed up with me and suggested we quit the camping trip and just go home. As we pulled into the drive way the phone was ringing. When my friend answered the phone it was my father in Perth Western Australia to tell us my mother had just died. My friend turned to me and said “Oh God, You’re freaky!”

My family is Catholic. My fathers heart stoped one and he was dead for a short time until paramedics revived him. He later said he did not experience anything supernatural or spiritual. He then developed cancer and ended up in a hospice. I was with him when he gasped his last breath, his heart stopped and his skin turned white from the loss of blood pressure. Then, nothing. That was it. No angels, no goodbye, no message in a dream. Nothing. Just dead and gone. My mother died some years later, suddenly and alone. I have not been to church much since then.

Not immediately but on the same day. One of my uncle (close relative) passed away a few years ago. All rituals for cremation were done on the same day in the evening. After everything was over, we returned back to our home. I was standing on the roof of my house with my cousins. I saw a strange whitish smoke in the human shape sweeping through the sky. I got scared and ran downstairs after telling my cousins that I need to drink water. I haven't told anyone about this till now.

Yes…my father in law had been quite ill, and we were called by his personal care worker from the seniors home, and told that he wasn’t well, so my wife and I went over. This was a good thing, for he passed a couple hours later. At that moment, he looked up at my wife as if to say goodbye…his eyes changed from normal to a grey, cloudy look. I’m sure that was the moment of death, perhaps his soul leaving his body. It was a profound experience, one I’ll never forget.

I have had more than my fair share of death in recent years. I have lost over 25 people since 2010, including my father, my grandfather, both of my husband’s grandparents, my only maternal first cousin, my sister, my brother, and my best friend. Causes ranged from pyroclastic pneumonia to freezing to death on Christmas morning. To say it has been difficult is a colossal understatement. What I have learned is this: you never know how someone is going to react in the aftermath of a death…including yourself.

As soon as someone dies, first thing that happens is change of perception of people ( distant relatives, not so close friends) for the deceased. When a person is alive mostly people have negative discussion behind the back of the person. Like how he never helped anyone his life or like how she never respected any one in the family etc. But as soon as the person is dead and we know he/she is never going to receive the negative words spoken about him/her through indirect channels; suddenly all the discussion changes to positive. Like how he helped you with money years ago when you were in need or  Continue Reading

My father had been taken to a hospice unit located about a hundred miles from the coastline where he lived. He passed away later that evening. When leaving hospice my wife and I noticed that the parking lot was literally filled with seagulls. We both stopped and just watched them. What made this so remarkable was my father's favorite pastime was driving to the beach, and drawings landscapes with seagulls in them. Maybe this sounds odd, but all I could say was thank you.

I grew up at a funeral home that my father owned. I think that the way a person's eyes go blank happens often. Unfortunately though, the most common thing to happen immediately after someone dies is their children begin to argue over who gets what. I plan on leaving very specific instructions if I ever have more children. (An only child has no one to split things up with)

I would like to share a story when my grandfather died. I remember my grand father talking to me in my dream “bala kalji ghe, me chalo” (take care son, I am leaving). And when I woke up I got call from my father about his dead. I was in complete shock and was actually able to see my grand father talking to me for couple of days. I am not sure what was that, but yes this is the true story.

Everything immediately becomes past tense. He used to love this song, remember? This was hers, but now it’s yours. When people reminisce over the antics and quirks of the deceased, they use the past tense in their sentences, and never the present. It’s a way of saying that what the dead did is past, and that they have moved on into another world.

More along the lines of Geraldine Cheung’s answer: It is a fact of English grammar that when people die, the past experiences of their life are always in the past tense, never in the perfect tense. For instance: (While alive) “He’s been to Europe, South America, and Antarctica.” (After death) “He went to Europe, South America, and Antarctica.” In talking about experiences that a living person has had in the past, the perfect is used because these events are still a part of a living person’s life, with relevance to the present. After the person dies, the past tense is used because the events happened  Continue Reading

when I was about 12 my mom passed from colon cancer. I and other were in the room. I can only say that in one instant there was something different. It was not a noise or any one reacting. The best description is her presence , was gone. Not a coldness- just subtle but very distinct change, like a light switch. Perhaps I could sense the lack of pain, but it was very discernable
